column5: OPEC has invited 14 othercrudeproducers, who together pump about a fifth of the world'soil, to talks this week in Vienna aimed at securing wider co-operation with production cuts. Russia already committed to reduce its output by 300,000 barrels a day following the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' (OPEC) agreement last week to a production cut of 1.2 million, Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo said. Major producers, including Mexico and Kazakhstan, along with relative minnows like Bolivia and Uzbekistan, have been asked to attend talks with OPEC ministers in Vienna on Dec. 10, he said. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: OPEC seeks crude oil cuts from 14 nations.
column10: NEW DELHIOPEC has invited 14 other crude producers, who together pump about a fifth of the world's oil, to talks this week in Vienna aimed at securing wider co-operation with production cuts.Russia already committed to reduce its output by 300,000 barrels a day following the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' (OPEC) agreement last week to a production cut of 1.2 million, Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo said. Major producers, including Mexico and Kazakhstan, along with relative minnows like Bolivia and Uzbekistan, have been asked to attend talks with OPEC ministers in Vienna on Dec. 10, he said.Oil prices have risen 18 per cent since OPEC's surprise agreement last week to make its first supply cuts in eight years, which was also the first accord since the late 1990s involving non-members. The new 32.5 million barrel-a-day production target is only slightly below the group's estimate for demand for its crude next year, meaning wider co-operation is needed to make a significant dent in the record stockpile surplus that has built up during three years of oversupply."It remains unclear to us which other non-OPEC producers might be willing to commit to or even claim production cuts," JBC Energy said in a note. "Although OPEC officials spoke of a 300,000 barrel-a-day contribution from Russia towards an overall 600,000 barrel-a-day non-OPEC cut, we remain quite skeptical that this will actually happen."After Russia, Mexico is the largest producer invited to Vienna. While the nation's output is expected to fall by about 150,000 barrels a day next year to 1.94 million due to the natural decline in production at aging fields, the country doesn't plan on any further cuts, a Pemex official said last week.Kazakhstan, the next-largest producer, with a daily output of about 1.7 million barrels, will decide on whether to cut output after talks with OPEC, the Astana-based Energy Ministry press service said in a statement Dec. 2.Oman, which pumps about one million barrels a day, has committed to matching any oil-output cut agreed by OPEC up to a maximum of 10 per cent.The other invitees are Bahrain, Colombia, Congo, Egypt, Trinidad and Tobago, Turkmenistan, Azerbaijan and Brunei. Altogether, the 14 nations pumped about 18.8 million barrels a day of oil last year, equivalent to 20 per cent of global supply, according to data from British Petroleum.OPEC agreed to a production cut of 1.2 million barrels last week.Ramzi Boudina/ReutersCopyright of Toronto Star (Canada) is the property of Toronto Star. column4: TECHNOLOGICAL innovationsPETROLEUM industryAUTOMATIONOPERATING costsOILfields
column5: The article offers information on several benefits offered by technological advances such as automation in theoiland gas industry. It mentions that automation could provide oilfields with various advantages which include monitoring capabilities, reduction in operating costs, and predictive maintenance.
column9: How Technology Is Changing the Oil and Gas Industry.
column10: New ProductsOnce considered to be merely on the horizon of the oil and gas industry, automation has taken center stage in recent years. With technological advancements catching up to the human imagination, there has been a gradual shift to automated technologies in virtually every industry. By reducing the time, error, and risk involved in human labor, today's sophisticated automation tools can be hugely beneficial to companies of all kinds.For the oil and gas industry, in particular, the shift to automation was as a matter of necessity. When prices for oil fell by 75% over 20 months beginning in 2014, the industry was forced to modernize. Four years later, prices have recovered, hitting record levels in the United States. With this new technology -- and the major advancements sure to come -- the oil and gas sector is poised for unprecedented success. But it is also important to consider whether these machines may replace workers, and how employees' duties may shift.The technology being used in the oil and gas industry today is highly sophisticated. At Devon's WellCon center, engineers are able to view a project remotely on screen, monitoring a 2-mile-long well being drilled 10,000 feet underground. If the drill wanders away from the "sweet spot" -- which can be as small as 10 feet across -- an alert is raised, and the engineers call the crew for adjustments. Such precision can only be achieved with a machine, making this one of many benefits the industry can gain from automation.Other key advantages include:* Monitoring capabilities -- With automation, oil and gas companies are able to keep track of their pipes and networks with an unprecedented amount of oversight. With systems like RealSens and investments in terminal automation, companies can monitor entire pipeline networks and remotely detect leaks. Plus, onshore and offshore pipelines are able to be observed for safety using autonomous underwater vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles. This is done to ward off criminal activity, terrorist attacks, and even repair damages. Weather monitoring systems, meanwhile, can be used to detect changes in seismic activity, as well as ocean and atmospheric levels.* Reduced operating costs -- According to McKinsey & Company, effective use of digital technologies could reduce capital expenditures by up to 20%.* Predictive maintenance -- Advanced analytics can now be implemented to detect issues preemptively, before equipment breaks down. By taking these proactive measures, companies can decrease maintenance costs by as much as 13%.* Reservoir limits -- Companies have been able to increase reservoir through the use of digital automation technologies.* Safety -- With automation, workers no longer have to go out into the field to make risky repairs. Instead, augmented reality can be used, or workers can operate drones to make needed repairs.* Efficiency in marketing and distribution -- Advanced analytics provide oil and gas companies with a better picture of consumer habits and desires, while allowing for optimized pricing models and more efficient supply chain management. For example, geospatial analytics can provide insight into route optimization and assist with location planning for different networks.Any discussion of automation will inevitably touch upon the technologies supplanting -- or shifting the roles of -- human labor. Though the industry has been doing well since the 2014 crisis, employment in the oil and gas sector is still down 21% since 2014. "It seems like they're doing more with less people," says Eric Neece a former roughneck for GE Oil & Gas, in a recent Wall Street Journal article.Devon, for example, is down 5,500 employees from December 2014, and laid off 300 workers this past April. Meanwhile, the company has invested more than $100 million in advanced technologies including fiber optic cables and augmented reality. As a result, towns built around the oil and gas economy have been affected, with old industry facilities being converted for other uses.Does this mean workers will be completely supplanted by automated technologies? No, says Jim Claunch, vice president of operational excellence for Statoil. "The more jewelry we put on the wells and pads out there, we're going to have people that are making sure the sensors are working and the communication is working -- the whole nine years."The human element will still be needed, just for different applications. Jon Krome of BHP Billiton says, "Is technology going to outsource everybody? The answer is absolutely not. Is it going to take an edge off of some of the very high-risk, perhaps most manual, of the labor force? Absolutely."In fact, the more refined these machines become, using algorithms to enhance their learning, the more workers will be able to perform their duties with enhanced safety, efficiency, and sophistication -- and less training. This will create new opportunities for more workers. Instead of being replaced, the "role of the human operator changes  They will be responsible for making sure they feed clean, relevant data into the algorithms," according to Peter Wang, a geophysical technical advisor for Paradigm.Automation offers a range of unique benefit for companies looking to improve their business operations and reduce costs, making technological investments a wise decision. For the people that these systems and tools are replacing, the transition is disruptive. However, these changes will ultimately be very beneficial for the industry as a whole.Ultimately, it is up to oil and gas companies to adjust. To illustrate this, Scott Desmarais of McKinsey & Co., cited the changing automotive industry as a parallel. "A mechanic 30 years ago didn't use electronics whatsoever. Today, they've almost got to be an electronic tech in addition to pulling that engine out."Lastly, though, consider this encouraging example in the oil and gas industry: Henry Hopkins of BP used to rely on instinct when deciding which wells to inspect. Now, a computer algorithm maps his route, and he uses augmented reality glasses to send a feed to BP technicians in Denver, who then send him directions and key data, showing him how to perform the complicated duties required. Hopkins is still needed. Knowing how these glasses work and his intimate knowledge of oil wells from years of hands-on experience make him a vital part of the team -- an ideal synthesis of technology and human labor.* https://www.wsj.com/articles/oils-new-technology-spells-end-of-boom-for -roughnecks-1531233085?&mod=djemfoe* https://www.eniday.com/en/technology%5Fen/automation-in-oil-gas-industry/* https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/ the-next-frontier-for-digital-technologies-in-oil-and-gas* https://www.rigzone.com/news/oil%5Fgas/a/151411/automation%5Fis%5Fthe%5Fkey%5Fto %5Fthe%5Ffuture%5Fof%5Foil%5Fand%5Fgas/* https://www.epmag.com/robotics-automation-and-changing-oil-gas-workforce -1669841* https://www.rigzone.com/news/oil%5Fgas/a/148741/oil%5Fgas%5Fleaders%5Fautomation %5Fabout%5Fefficiency%5Fnot%5Fjob%5Felimination/?all=hg2* https://news.thomasnet.com/fluid-gas-flow/2014/08/13/carbide-coatings -terminal-automation-are-more-opportunities-in-oil-and-gas* https://news.thomasnet.com/fluid-gas-flow/2013/08/21/new-technology-could -reduce-oil-pipeline-leaksImage Credit: manine99/Shutterstock.comTechnician sitting in a control room monitoring a process petrochemical plant.By Conor McGladeCopyright of ThomasNet News is the property of Thomas Publishing Company LLC and its content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. However, users may print, download, or email articles for individual use.

column5: DUBAI, 20th September, 2015 (WAM) -- The Department ofOilAffairs in the Government of Dubai has announced that it has notified its customers that the official price of Dubaicrudeoilto be delivered next April, will be US$0.20 less
column9: Department of Oil announces Dubai crude oil price for April delivery
column10: DUBAI, 20th September, 2015 (WAM) -- The Department of Oil Affairs in the Government of Dubai has announced that it has notified its customers that the official price of Dubai crude oil to be delivered next April, will be US$0.20 lessthan the average daily settlement price of the Oman Crude Oil Financial Contractin Dubai Mercantile Exchange contracts traded over the next month.Abdullah Abdul Karim, Director-General of the Department, told Emirates News Agency, WAM, that the department sets the price of Dubai crude oil in the markets in parallel with Oman oil prices, which reinforces the transparency of pricing process commitment and setting a fair value of crude oil in the Middle East.The official monthly price of Dubai crude oil, with the transition to the pricing of futures contracts, is determined in advance, and a differential price is placed three months prior, “M-3”, while the official final monthly price is determined at the end of the second month, “M-2”.DME Oman crude oil is considered a benchmark for pricing crude oil by the countries that produce it, and it gives them a differential price that reflects the quality of the product.Every day at 12:30 p.m. Dubai time, Dubai Mercantile Exchange determines the daily settlement price of the Oman contract, which is the average price of transactions made in the five minutes from 12:25 p.m. to 12:30 p.m., Dubai time.On the last circulating day of the month, the settlement's window lasts for thirty minutes from 12:00 p.m. until 12:30 p.m., Dubai time.Copyright 2016 by Emirates News Agency Distributed by UPICopyright of Arabia 2000 is the property of Arabia 2000.  The copyright in an individual article may be maintained by the author in certain cases.  Content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. However, users may print, download, or email articles for individual use. Source: Arabia 2000, Jan 26, 2016Item: 6FI3543030004

column2: Central Asia & Caucasus Business Weekly. 2/13/2018, p1-1. 1p.
column5: ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The government of Kazakhstan will revise macroeconomic parameters upwards, in particular, a budget referenceoilprice for this year, Deputy Minister of National Economy Ruslan Dalenov said. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: Kazakh 2018 budget may assume higher crude oil price.
column10:
CONTENTSBUSINESS & ECONOMYKazakh 2018 budget may assume higher crude oil priceASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The government of Kazakhstan will revise macroeconomic parameters upwards, in particular, a budget reference oil price for this year, Deputy Minister of National Economy Ruslan Dalenov said."First of all, it's a crude oil price. Earlier the budget was based on $45 a barrel for this year. The oil price currently is slightly more than $ 60 per barrel, while the consensus forecast of the UN, WB and IMF averages $58. We are now considering what budget benchmark price to pick for this year," Dalenov said at a briefing in Astana.The parameters for exports and manufacturing industry will also be revised up.He noted, the economic situation in the country has improved, as a whole."GDP grew by 4% in 2017, which is higher than the average rate in the world and neighboring countries. I can say that today there is no crisis in the country, "he said.BUSINESS & ECONOMYNazarbayev instructs government toÂ take control ofÂ rural budgetsASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax) - Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev has instructed the government jointly with the regional governors to take control of the issue of budgets of rural communities."At the level of the rural settlements, where more than two thousand people live, local self-government will be introduced, this is the fourth tier of the budget. The collection of 7 types of taxes was transferred to the communities and expenditures are also executed in 19 aspects. According to preliminary analysis, only 11% of rural areas can be self-sufficient and able to cover expenses at the expense of their own incomes. Therefore, the government together with the regional authorities need to take control of this issue, " Nazarbayev said on Friday at a meeting with the regional governors, the mayors of the cities of Astana and Almaty.BUSINESS & ECONOMYKazakhstan's economy grew 4% inÂ Jan - economy ministryASTANA. Feb 13(Interfax) - Kazakhstan's economy grew 4% in January 2018, Minister of the National Economy Timur Suleimenov said."During the first month of 2018, GDP grew by 4%, against 2.4% in January 2017," Suleimenov said at a government meeting on Tuesday in Astana.The main driving forces behind the growth were rising industrial output, higher investment demand, and rebounding domestic consumption.The macroeconomic environment has strengthened given slower inflation. Since the beginning of the year, inflation was 0.6%, a record low since the beginning of inflation targeting in August 2015. In annual terms, inflation was at 6.8% in January, Suleimenov said."The contribution of the non-primary sector increased to 71% of GDP, against 60% last year," he said.The mining industry grew 4.5% due to a 7% increase in oil production, 7.2% rise in gas production, and 3.8% rise in iron-ore mining.Manufacturing increased by 6.2%, including in the chemical industry (15.6%), the paper industry (13.7%), beverages (10.5%), and furniture-making (10.1%).The pharmaceutical industry continued to show steady growth (7.9%), as did machine-building (7.9%), metal-making (7.4%), and food production (6%).The agriculture sector grew 3.7% thanks to a 3.9% rise in livestock production.After high growth in January 2017, the construction sector recorded a 14.9% decline "due to a slowdown in pipeline projects in the Atyrau region and the completion of EXPO facilities and the expansion of the Astana Airport," Suleimenov said.Trade increased 7.5% largely due to a 9.3% expansion of wholesale trade in gas, oil, and oil products, oil service equipment, work clothes, machinery, pharmaceutical goods, tobacco products, grain, and food products.In January 2018, investments in fixed assets increased by 65.4%, driven by the modernization of the Shymkent refinery of PetroKazakhstan Oil Products, the construction of a third-generation injection (3GI) plant at the Tengiz field, and the construction of an advanced oil-processing center at the Atyrau refinery.Kazakhstan's foreign-exchange reserves, including the reserves of the National Bank and the National Fund, totaled $90.071 billion as of January 31, a month-on-month increase of 1.1%, the National Bank said.The assets of the National Fund are estimated at $68.347 billion, an increase of 0.05%.The gross international reserves of the National Bank totaled $31.724 billion, a 3.2% increase.The net international reserves of the National Bank rose 3.2% to $31.199 billion.Assets in foreign currencies rose 2.2% to $18.639 billion; gold assets rose 4.7% to $13.985 billion.BUSINESS & ECONOMYFixed capital investment upÂ 65.4% inÂ Kazakhstan inÂ JanALMATY. Feb 13 (Interfax) - Fixed capital investment in January 2018 increased 65.4% year-on-year to 636.881 billion tenge, the Statistics Committee of the National Economy Ministry said.The most attractive industries for investment were mining (46.7% of all fixed capital investment), transportation real estate transactions (7.9%) and stockpiling (6.5%), according to statistics.Investment (421.6 billion tenge) mostly came from equity capital (66.2% of total investment in January 2018), public money (1%), bank loans (26.8% including 2% worth of loans from foreign banks) and borrowed funds (6% including 0.6% worth of borrowings from non-residents).BUSINESS & ECONOMYJanuary industrial production inÂ Kazakhstan upÂ 5.2% year-on-yearASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - Industrial output in Kazakhstan in January was 5.2% higher than in January 2017, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of the National Economy said.The mining industry expanded 4.5%, the manufacturing industry grew 5.2%, and supplies of electricity, gas, and steam rose 5.4%, while water supply dropped 4.3%.The output of crude oil, natural gas, and iron ore increased. An upward trend in production was also observed in the areas of food, beverages, rubber and plastic products, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, metals, and machinery. Decreases in output were seen in coal and lignite, non-ferrous metal ores, tobacco products, and textiles.Production increased in 11 regions of Kazakhstan.Producer prices for industrial products and services in Kazakhstan rose 1.4% month-on-month in January 2017, the Ministry said.Prices grew 2.6% in the manufacturing industry and 0.4% in the mining industry; prices for industrial products and services rose 0.9% and 6.3%, respectively.Producer prices for coal increased 6%, for diesel 1.4%, for heating oil 0.7%, and for crude oil, gasoline, and metal ores 0.3%. They decreased 0.3% for liquefied propane and butane. Prices for ferroalloys rose 16.4%, for rolled iron 3.5%, and for lead 1.1%, while those for aluminum fell 3.4%, for zinc 2.3%, for precious metals 2%, and for copper 0.5%.Producer prices for tea rose 2.2%, for vegetable oil 1.9%, for dairy products 1.1%, and for rice 0.5%; those for wheat flour fell 2.2%, for cereals 1.4%, and for sugar 1.2%.Prices for imported goods in Kazakhstan in 2017 rose by 6.8% and export prices by 21.2%, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of National Economy said.In 2017, the prices for commodity imports went up by 7%, commodity exports increased by 15.2% in price. Imported semi-finished products rose in price by 10.7%, exported items grew by 7.9%. The prices for imported finished products increased by 7.8% and for exported items by 2% in the reporting year.Last year saw an increase in export prices for ferrous metals (44.2%), zinc (26.5%), copper (21%), coal (16%), oil (29.5%), lead (9.4%), cotton (7.5%) and their decrease for manganese ore (19.5%), wheat (6.7%) and wool (6.6%).The import prices in 2017 rose for alcohol and soft drinks (14.6%), dairy products (11%), macaroni (7.3%), tea (4.7%), poultry (4.7%), medications (3.5%), paper (13.3%), textile goods (7.6%), footwear (5.9%), while import prices fell for vegetables (22.2%), fruit and nuts (2%).In January 2018 the volume of retail trade grew 4.3% year-on-year to 625.7 billion tenge, the Ministry said.Enterprises sold goods in the retail business sector 2.4% more than in January last year; the volume of trade by individual sellers grew 7.1%.As at February 1, 2018, the total stock of the trade organizations stood at 483.8 billion tenge or equivalent to 67 trading days.In January, the structure of total sales was dominated by non-food products in Kazakhstsan(69.1% of the total volume), the share of food products was 30.9%; retail sales of foodstuffs rose 7.5% year-on-year, of non-food products up 3%.BUSINESS & ECONOMYTax-to-GDP ratio inÂ 2018 expected toÂ reach 17% - Kazakh MinFinALMATY. Feb 9 (Interfax) - Tax revenues as a percentage of GDP are expected to rise to 17% in 2018, Kazakhstan's Finance Minister Bakhyt Sultanov said."Finally, we've managed to reverse the trend of dwindling tax revenues with respect to GDP. In 2016, this indicator fell to 15.2%; last year, it went above 16% against a 15.8% target. The government's Department of Revenues is set to bring the ratio to 25% by 2025. This year, we plan to approach a benchmark of 17%," Sultanov said at a government meeting in Astana on Friday."A further increase in the collection of revenues will be achieved through the digitization of tax and customs administration. The electronic tax and customs initiative will bring tax and customs revenues up to 6.5 trillion tenge by 2025," he added.BUSINESS & ECONOMYKazakhstan toÂ lower national debt toÂ 23.7% ofÂ GDP byÂ 2022ASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - The national debt of Kazakhstan, now 26% of DGP, is expected to decrease to 23.7% by 2022, Minister of the National Economy Timur Suleimenov said."We must establish tight control over the national debt [...] According to the social and economic growth outlook through 2022, it should decrease to 23.7% [of GDP]," Suleimenov said at a meeting of the government in Astana on Tuesday."There is also a covenant under the national strategy for the use of currency assets of the National Fund. At the moment, the covenant is set at 97.5%, so this issue is under our control," he said.The Ministry of the National Economy has resolved to create an interagency commission that will be tasked with setting a ceiling for external debt for quasi-public sector entities."The document is now with the Ministry of Justice and will be presented to the office [of the prime minister] in the near future. This year, we will be working with all entities of the quasi-public sector in order to set a limit on their external debt," Suleimenov said.BUSINESS & ECONOMYDraft Kazakh law onÂ special economic and industrial zones toÂ be adopted inÂ H1ASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - The draft law on special economic zones and industrial zones will be submitted to the president for signature in the first half of this year, Minister of Investment and Development Zhenis Kasymbek said."Last year we conducted a detailed analysis of the special economic zones for their efficiency. Today we are trying to fill the legislative gaps. The draft law on special economic zones and industrial zones is now being reviewed by the Majilis of the parliament. We expect the document to be submitted to the head of state for signature in the first half of the year," Kasymbek said at a Tuesday meeting of the government.Last week President Nursultan Nazarbayev instructed the government to assess the performance of all special economic zones (SEZ)."Large public funds have been allocated to eleven SEZs, 283 billion tenge, but governors keep filing proposals for new SEZs. Unless the effectiveness of those eleven SEZs is assessed, there will be no new ones," Nazarbayev said at an extended meeting of the government last Friday.The head of state cited the example of the Taraz Special Economic Zone, which failed to set up a single production facility in six years it has been operating.ENERGY & RESOURCESKazakhstan boosts exports ofÂ oil, concentrate 12.4% inÂ 2017ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax) - Kazakhstan's exports of oil and condensate totaled 69.8 million tonnes in 2017, a 12.4% increase on 2016, materials for a Cabinet meeting headed by the President said.Kazakhstan produced 72.932 million tonnes of oil and 13.269 million tonnes of gas condensate, an 11.2% and 6.5% growth respectively.The production plan for oil and condensate in 2018 is 87 million tonnes.Kazakhstan is part of the OPEC+ agreement to cut oil production in an attempt to stabilize the oil market.ENERGY & RESOURCESKazakhstan targets 6% increase inÂ refining inÂ 2018ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The oil refining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries in 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes, 6% higher than actual refining in 2017 and 9% higher than the refining target last year, according to the factsheet prepared for an expanded government meeting in Astana on Friday.Domestic refineries processed 14.9 million tonnes of crude oil in 2017 (compared with the target of 14.5 million tonnes), 2.8% more than in 2016.Petroleum bitumen output is expected to amount to 740,000 tonnes in 2018.In 2017, Kazakhstan produced 731,000 tonnes of bitumen or an increase of 46.7% from 2016. Kazakhstan exported 97,000 tonnes of bitumen to Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and China in 2017.Coal production is targeted at 107 million tonnes in 2018 compared with actual production of 111.118 million tonnes in 2017.The level of gasification in the country is slated to rise to 47.65% from 47.38% as of the end of 2017."Sixteen gasification projects at a total cost of 12.8 billion tenge will be carried out in six regions this year: Jambyl, South Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, West Kazakhstan and Almaty regions," the materials say.ENERGY & RESOURCESKazakhstan's share inÂ Kashagan safely protected - MinisterASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - The Ministry of Justice of Kazakhstan to present arguments of the Statis' fraud in an appeal against freezing Kazakhstan's stake in the Kashagan oil field, Justice Minister Marat Beketayev said."The prospects for Stati collecting the award at the expense of Kashagan's stake are minimal. Any actions on managing shares in the oil project is bound to the oil production agreement. Project participants must be first approved by the regulator, the Ministry of Energy. This is the first level of protection," Beketayev told reporters in Astana on Tuesday."Kazakhstan objects to the arbitration award and will never grant an approval. Interfering in the oil production agreement is impossible without a government consent. Therefore, the media have to assure the public that the share in Kashagan is safely protected," Beketayev said."The Ministry of Justice has not participated in this litigation regarding a share in Kashagan, because Samruk-Kazyna is a stakeholder," the Minister said.The State Welfare Fund has not presented all arguments that the Ministry of Justice has been using, he said."Samruk-Kazyna argued that it's an independent legal entity that bears no responsibility for government's obligations. At the stage of appeal, the Justice Ministry will join the proceedings and present all its arguments, including a massive fraud scheme," Beketayev said.In the last four years Kazakhstan has been involved in a series of court proceedings in connection with the arbitration proceedings initiated by Anatolie Stati, his son Gabriel Stati and their two companies Ascom Group S.A. and Terra Raf Trans Trading Ltd who filed a lawsuit claim of over $4 billion.In January an Amsterdam court upheld the decision to freeze half of Kazakhstan's stake in the Kashagan oil field valued at $5.2 billion. The assets were frozen as part of Stati arbitration award of about $500 million against Kazakhstan.In December 2017 as part of this case nearly $22 billion of Kazakhstan's National Fund (40% of its total volume) was frozen by the Bank of New York Mellon Corp.Kazakhstan, through discovery proceedings in the US, obtained information and documents that revealed that Stati had engaged for years in Kazakhstan in a massive fraudulent scheme. The essence of the fraud was that through a series of undisclosed related party transactions and falsified financial statements, and having had entered into fictitious contracts, the Statis had fraudulently inflated the construction costs of a liquefied petroleum gas plant in Kazakhstan. Furthermore, they had made false statements in front of the international arbitral tribunal.In October 2015, State Fund Samruk-Kazyna acquired KazMunayGas' 50%-stake in the Kashagan project leaving the national company with the right to buy back shares in accordance with an option agreement.In January this year it became known that KazMunaiGas extended for two years the buy-back option regarding this stake in Kashagan currently owned by Samruk-Kazyna. Under an additional agreement for the option agreement signed by Cooperatieve KazMunaiGaz U.A. (based in Netherlands and 98.88% KMG-owned) and Samruk-Kazyna, the 2018-2020 option deadline was extended for a new period scheduled for 2020-22.Kashagan is Kazakhstan's first offshore oil and gas field in the Caspian Sea. It is the largest international investment project in the country. Oil commercial production at Kashagan started on November 1, 2016.Kashagan is developed by North Caspian Operating Company (NCOC) that is owned by KMG Kashagan B.V. (16.877%), Shell Kazakhstan Development B.V. (16.807%), Total EP Kazakhstan (16.807%), AgipCaspian Sea B.V. (16.807%), ExxonMobil Kazakhstan Inc. (16.807%), CNPC Kazakhstan B.V. (8.333%) and Inpex NorthCaspian Sea Ltd. (7.563%).ENERGY & RESOURCESKazMunayGas may hold IPO inÂ 2019ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax) - KazMunayGas may hold an IPO in 2019, according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday."JSC National Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC and National Company KazMunayGas JSC expressed their intent in a joint letter dated June 6, 2017 to include the Atyrau refinery in the IPO of National Company KazMunayGas JSC. Taking into consideration this letter and the terms and conditions of the [privatization] program, National Company KazMunayGas JSC will supposedly hold IPO in 2019," the document says.Minister of National Economy Timur Suleimenov told Interfax earlier that KazMunayGas will privatized as a vertically integrated holding company.National Company KazMunayGas JSC is a national operator for exploration, production, processing and transportation of hydrocarbons. The company represents the state interests in the oil and gas sector of Kazakhstan. KazMunayGas is owned by Samruk-Kazyna National Wealth Fund (90%) and by the National Bank of Kazakhstan (10%).RefiningThe government of Kazakhstan is in talks with the Karachaganak stakeholders about construction of a fourth refinery, President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev said."We are modernizing all our three refineries. The shortage of gasoline will be covered in the next three-four years. Then we will have to import gasoline again. When I talked earlier about the urgent need to build a fourth refinery, I was told that we did not need it. We only start doing something when we are faced with a problem. I know that we all are working on this issue. We have had a talk with the Karachaganak investors. We need to speed up the decision-making on a [fourth] refinery," Nazarbayev said at the government meeting.The government of Kazakhstan is in talks with the Karachaganak stakeholders about production sharing calculations. The talks have been extended until the end of the 3rd quarter of 2018.One of the prerequisites for termination of the dispute about production sharing calculations may be construction of a production facility, which has yet to be decided upon.In April 2016, the Ministry of Energy said that there were certain controversial issues regarding the Karachaganak project that relate to production sharing calculations.The Financial Times said last year referring to people familiar with the situation that KPO had offered to pay about $300m to settle a dispute with the Kazakh government over the Karachaganak oil and gas field but the government had rejected the offer.Last year, some media quoted Lukoil as saying that Kazakhstan claimed about $1.6 billion from the Karachaganak partners under the production sharing agreement (PSA) on the Karachaganak field.Minister of Energy Kanat Bozumbayev said earlier that Kazakhstan would back out of the arbitration process if the government was satisfied with the dispute resolution proposal from the Karachaganak shareholders.The oil refining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries for 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes or 9% higher than in 2017, the meeting's factsheet stated.In 2017 the domestic refineries processed 14.9 million tonnes of crude oil compared to the target of 14.5 million tonnes or an increase of 2.8% from 2016.The output of oil bitumen in 2018 is expected to amount to 740,000 tonnes.In 2017 Kazakhstan produced 731,000 tonnes of bitumen or an increase of 46.7% from 2016. Last year the republic exported 97,000 tonnes of bitumen to Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and China.There are three refineries in Kazakhstan: Atyrau, Pavlodar and Shymkent.Gas suppliesKazakhstan will implement 16 domestic gas supply projects in six regions of the country in 2018."In 2018 we will implement 16 domestic gas supply projects in six regions (Zhambyl, South Kazakhstan, Aktobe, Kyzylorda, West Kazakhstan and Almaty regions) for a total amount of 12.8 billion tenge."The share of households that have access to domestic gas services will account for 47.65% in 2018 compared with 47.38% in 2017.The Energy Ministry of Kazakhstan set the sale gas production target for 2018 at 31.9 billion cubic meters.CoalKazakhstan plans to produce 107 million tonnes of coal in 2018 or a decrease of 3.7% from a year earlier.In 2017, Kazakhstan produced 111.118 million tonnes of coal.Kazakhstan has coal mines in the Karaganda, Pavlodar and East Kazakhstan regions.ENERGY & RESOURCESTengizchevroil oil output upÂ 4.1% inÂ 2017ALMATY. Feb 13 (Interfax) - Kazakh oil company Tengizchevroil (TCO) produced 28.7 million tonnes of oil in 2017, up 4.1% on 2016 production of 27.56 million tonnes."TCO has had another record year for oil production with 28.7 million tonnes," CEO Ted Etchiston said at a press conference on Tuesday in Almaty.Sales of liquefied natural gas (LNG) totaled 1.38 million tonnes, up from 1.35 million tonnes in 2016, dry gas sales - 7.45 bcm compared to 7.21 bcm and 2.49 million tonnes of sulfur, up from 2.33 million tonnes.The CEO also said that direct payments by the company to Kazakhstan totaled $8.5 billion. "As you know, oil prices have been falling sharply for over three years which has led to a reduction in payments to Kazakhstan since 2015. However, the figure for 2017 was slightly better," he said.TCO paid $4.7 billion in 2016, meaning payments were up 1.8-fold in 2017.Etchiston said that in total, since 1993 to December 31, 2017, direct payments to the country have reached $125 billion, including the salaries of Kazakh employees, purchases of goods and services from local producers and suppliers, payments to state companies, dividend payments to its Kazakh partner as well as taxes and royalties.TCO bought over $2.5 billion worth of goods and services from Kazakh suppliers last year and $24 billion since it started operations in Kazakhstan.TCO develops the Tengiz and Korolev fields in the Atyrau Region of Kazakhstan. The partners in Tengizchevroil LLP are Chevron with 50%, ExxonMobil Kazakhstan Ventures Inc with 25% and the Kazakhstan via state-owned company KazMunayGaz with 20% as well as Russian-American JV LUKArco with the remaining 5%.ENERGY & RESOURCESNostrum Oil & Gas places $400 mln inÂ 7-year EurobondsALMATY. Feb 9 (Interfax) - Nostrum Oil & Gas, an independent Kazakh company which develops and conducts exploration at hydrocarbon fields in the Pre-Caspian Basin, has placed $400 million in Eurobonds with a 7% coupon, the company said in a statement on the London Stock Exchange.Banca IMI, Citi, Deutsche and VTB Capital were joint book-runners for the placement."Funds from the Eurobond placement will be partially used to buy Eurobonds of subsidiary Zhaikmunai LLP which mature in 2019 and used for general corporate purposes," the statement said.International ratings agency Moody's Investor Service earlier assigned older Nostrum Oil & Gas unsecured Eurobonds with the rating "B2".Nostrum Oil & Gas Plc is the parent company of Kazakh company Zhaikmunai LLP.ENERGY & RESOURCESKazakh energy ministry lobbies for local content asÂ part ofÂ Karachaganak expansion project procurementASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - Kazakhstan's Energy Ministry has succeeded in lobbying for local content inclusion in design procurement under the forthcoming Karachaganak expansion project.Now as part of the Karachaganak [oil field] expansion project estimated at several billion US dollars a requirement is offered so that designs must be carried out jointly with a Kazakh partner, that is a Kazakh design research company must carry out at least 50% of the scope of designs in Kazakhstan. This stipulation is proposed with regard to the Karachaganak project, CEO of the Union of Oilfield Services Companies Nurlan Zhumagulov told a press conference.KPO invited all the foreign contractors and told them to create joint ventures if they are willing to work under the project, he said.At the same time Zhumagulov told Interfax-Kazakhstan that these agreements on local content regarding design procurement are not legally binding.Karachaganak Petroleum Operating (KPO) has been developing the Karachaganak field since 1997 on the basis of a 40-year production sharing agreement (PSA). Karachaganak oil and gas condensate field is one of the largest in the world, its reserves are estimated at 1.2 billion tonnes of oil and 1.34 trillion cubic meters of gas. In Kazakhstan, similar subsoil use contracts contain fixed terms and conditions, as well as a fixed tax burden, so requirements stipulating at least 50% local content do not apply to PSAs. However, in recent years the Kazakh authorities have been lobbying for the interests of local oilfield service companies negotiating with the operators of major oil and gas projects in order to invite Kazakh contractors to expansion projects. This policy resulted in a decision by the shareholders of Tengizchevroil developing the Tengiz oil field to allocate $12 billion for works and services procurement from Kazakh companies; this expansion project value totals $ 37 billion.ENERGY & RESOURCESKazakhstan toÂ consider options for new refineryASTANA. Feb 13 (Interfax) - A roadmap containing various options for the construction of a fourth refinery in Kazakhstan will be submitted to the interagency commission on Thursday, Energy Minister Kanat Bozumbayev said."We have created a new working group to review all possible options for the construction of a new refinery and decide on its financing and dates of talks with potential investors. This working group will develop a roadmap that will be submitted to the interagency commission on Thursday," Bozumbayev said a meeting of the government on Tuesday.The other working group, consisting of international experts and representatives of government agencies, has reviewed the expected balance between production and consumption of gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel and concluded that the existing refineries will be able to satisfy domestic demand, even after their modernization, only in the medium term, the minister said."Taking into account the expected growth in consumption, the domestic market will face a shortage of gasoline between 2021 and 2023, of diesel between 2018 and 2023, and of jet fuel after 2026," Bozumbayev said.There are three refineries in Kazakhstan: the Shymkent refinery, built in 1985, which is owned by KazMunaiGas and CNPC on a parity basis, and the Atyrau and Pavlodar refineries, built in 1945 and 1978, which are controlled wholly by KazMunaiGas.ENERGY & RESOURCESSouth Korean Hanwha Total Petrochemical interested inÂ Kazakh gas chemical complex projectASTANA. Feb 7 (Interfax) - It is inadmissible to politicize issues related to the work of Kyrgyzstan's mining companies, Kyrgyz President Sooronbai Jeenbekov said."The mining industry is one of the main budget-revenue-generating sectors of the country's economy and creates jobs for the population [...] The politicization of issues related to activities of mining companies is absolutely inadmissible," Jeenbekov said during a meeting with Ulanbek Ryskulov, the chair of the State Committee for Industry, Energy, and Natural Resource Management, on Wednesday.It is possible to avoid social discontent over mining in the regions by means of conducting transparent competitions and auctions, as well as through increasing the awareness of the population, the Kyrgyz president said.Discussing investment policy in this sector, Jeenbekov mentioned the importance of "creating favorable conditions for investors and [of] clear monitoring of their fulfillment of statutory obligations.""Only environmental experts can determine exactly whether a mining company complies with the ecological security standards or not," Jeenbekov said."If it is proven that activities of a mining company don't comply with the requirements of the republic's legislation and are detrimental to ecological safety, then such projects should not be implemented in the country," Jeenbekov said."Kyrygzstan's national wealth should be used for the benefit of the country and in compliance with all environmental norms," he said.Jeenbekov also recommended that the state committee involve representatives of local communities in environmental monitoring in areas where mining companies are active, visit facilities more often, review enterprises' operations thoroughly, and work closely with citizens.Last week, local residents of the southern Jalal-Abad and Batken regions held protests against the development of the Makmal and Shambesay goldmines in the Toguz-Torouz district of the Jalal-Abad region and the Feb 12 (Interfax) - Protests by local residents have prompted suspension of construction work on a gold recovery plant at the Makmal gold deposit in the Toguz-Torouz district of Kyrgyzstan's southern Jalal-Abad Region.The residents of the village of Kazarman have for several weeks been protesting against the development of the Makmal deposit and construction of a gold recovery plant on the site by the company Ji El Makmal Development. They demanded that miners adhere to ecological regulations and claimed that dangerous compounds used in processing ores subsequently make their way into the water and soil."The Toguz-Torouz deputy district head and local council deputies met with the protestors several times, but the awareness-building was not successful, with local residents continuing to demand a cessation of construction, expressing concern over the ecological situation in the district," a district administration official told Interfax."Following the latest protest, residents said that they were prepared for drastic measures should work on the plant continue, and construction works were stopped so as not to escalate the situation," he said.Ji El Makmal Development in turn told journalists that construction of the gold recovery plant has not stopped but is merely on hold as "not all authorization documents have yet been received."In an earlier meeting with chair of the State Committee for Industry, Energy, and Natural Resource Management Ulanbek Ryskulov, Kyrgyz President Sooronbai Jeenbekov said that "only environmental experts can determine exactly whether a mining company complies with ecological security standards or not," and called for "not politicizing this matter."In addition to that, Jeenbekov also recommended that the state committee involve representatives of local communities in environmental monitoring in areas where mining companies are active, visit facilities more often, review enterprises' operations thoroughly, and work closely with local citizens.Until 2003, Makmalzoloto, a subdivision of gold-miner JSC Kyrgyzaltyn, mined the Makmal deposit by the open pit method. Feb 12 (Interfax) - Turkmenistan will produce 2,030 tonnes of silkworm cocoons in 2018, a slight reduction over 2017.President of Turkmenistan Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow has signed the relevant decree, the Neutral Turkmenistan newspaper said in a report.In the 2017 season, the country's silkworm breeders produced and delivered to the state 2,040 tonnes of silkworm cocoons, an increase of 2% over 2016 figures. The 2017 plan had called for 2,030 tonnes.The primary production enterprises in the industry are the Ashgabat Silk-reeling Factory and the Turkmenabat Silk Production Association.CONSTRUCTION & PROPERTYNew house prices inÂ Kazakhstan remain unchanged inÂ JanASTANA. Feb 8 (Interfax) - In January 2018, the prices of newly built homes and flats in Kazakhstan stood unchanged compared do December 2017, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economy said.Last month in the residential resale property market the prices for apartments edged up 0.1%, the accommodations rent up 0.3%, according to statistics.Average sales prices of newly built housing space in Kazakhstan amounted to 260,203 tenge per square meter, of resold housing space to 185,942 tenge per square meter and the apartment rent was 1,333 tenge on average per square meter.Residential real estate transactions in Kazakhstan in January 2018 increased 1.2% year-on-year to make 16,380 deals, the Ministry said.POLITICS & SOCIETYSouth Korean president toÂ visit Kazakhstan inÂ MayASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax) - The Chairman of the Kazakh Senate's Committee on Constitutional Legislation, Judiciary, and Law Enforcement, Georgy Kim, has met with South Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Sye-kyun to discuss in political, trade, economic, transport, industrial, and innovation cooperation, the Kazakh Senate's press service said in a statement."This year is full of important bilateral events and meetings. The visit of South Korean President Moon Jae-in to Kazakhstan in late May 2018 will be a milestone event," Kim said.The joint declaration of enhanced strategic partnership signed during the state visit of Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev to Seoul on November 9-11, 2016 is very important, he said.The sides declared the importance of inter-parliamentary contacts to strengthen bilateral relations as a whole. They also agreed to develop contacts between parliamentary friendship groups, and Kazakh Senate Speaker Kassym-Jomart Tokayev invited Chung to pay an official visit to Astana this year.Kim informed Chung about Kazakhstan's investment legislation and economic plans and invited Korean businessmen to set up joint ventures in Kazakhstan. He said that cooperation in agriculture, tourism, transport, logistics, and high technology present mutual interest.On the topic of a settlement for the Korean Peninsula, Kim stressed the importance of the measures taken by Kazakhstan during its presidency of the UN Security Council in January 2018."Kazakhstan hopes that the establishment of a dialogue and North Korea's participation in the PyeongChang Games will help de-escalate tensions on the Korean Peninsula," Kim said.POLITICS & SOCIETYKazakhstan toÂ start using Latin-based Kazakh for passports and IDs inÂ 2021-2023ASTANA. Feb 13(Interfax) - The Ministry of Culture and Sports of Kazakhstan has presented a three-stage plan for adopting a Latin-based script for writing the Kazakh language, Deputy Minister of Culture and Sports Yerlan Kozhagapanov said at a government meeting in Astana on Tuesday.The first stage (through 2020) will involve the adoption and perfection of new spelling rules and the creation of applications to convert Kazakh texts from Cyrillic to Latin script."The second stage (2021-2023) provides for passports, identity cards, and other documents to be issued in the Latin-based Kazakh alphabet," Kozhagapanov said."The third stage (2024-2025) involves introducing Latinized Kazakh for record-keeping at local executive bodies, educational institutions, state media outlets, and state publications," he said.The ministry will create the Til Kazyna Center to coordinate all stages of the work.President Nursultan Nazarbayev signed a decree on switching the Kazakh writing system from Cyrillic to Latin in October 2017. The document calls for the gradual introduction of a Latin-based script by 2025.POLITICS & SOCIETYUzbekistan toÂ issue short-term visas toÂ transit passengers, allow tourists toÂ take photosTASHKENT. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Uzbek President Shavkat Mirziyoyev has signed a resolution on measures promoting inbound tourism, which involves the issue of short-term visas to transit passengers.The resolution was signed on Tuesday and published in Uzbek media on Wednesday.The purpose of this document's proposals is to increase inbound tourism, make it a key sector of the national economy, and promote the country's cultural and historical heritage and natural resources."Starting May 1, 2018, [it is resolved] to issue short-term visas to transit passengers for a 72-hour period on the condition that they have a plane ticket and a visa [if necessary] to a third country and pay the consular fee, as well as to establish the procedure for their short-term supervised departure from the airport's border zone on sightseeing tours with approved itineraries," the resolution reads.Uzbekistan's national airline has been allowed to sell international flights for less than their cost in order to make those flights competitive.The resolution lifts every ban on tourists' taking photos and videos of public places and buildings, except in places where photographing and filming is prohibited by legislation.Previously, Mirziyoyev issued an executive order endorsing 30-day visa-free travel for citizens of Israel, Indonesia, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Turkey, and Japan starting February 10. Currently, citizens of Azerbaijan, Armenia, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Moldova, Russia, Ukraine, and Kyrgyzstan (up to 60 days) are entitled to visa-free travel.The order also liberalized the issuance of tourist visas to citizens of 39 countries starting February 10.ELECTIONSHead ofÂ CIS Executive Committee toÂ lead mission toÂ observe Turkmen parliamentary electionsASHGABAT. Feb 7 (Interfax) - The head of the CIS Executive Committee and the organization's Executive Secretary Sergei Lebedev will head a CIS observer mission during the elections to the Turkmen parliament, Turkmen media have reported.Some 70 CIS representatives will monitor the election, they say.March 25 is voting day. Monitors will begin working on March 2.ELECTIONSTajik deputies approve reducing minimum age ofÂ presidential candidates from 35 toÂ 30DUSHANBE. Feb 7 (Interfax) - The lower chamber of the Tajik parliament has approved amendments to the republic's age limit for presidential candidates and members of parliament, Tajik media reported on Wednesday."People who have turned 30 can now be elected president of the country or members of the upper chamber of the parliament of Tajikistan. These amendments follow from the changes made to the Constitution of Tajikistan adopted on May 22, 2016 based on the outcome of a nationwide referendum. The age limits were then reduced from 35 to 30 years," the report said.An amendment was also made to the Law on Presidential Elections under which an officially registered presidential candidate can only be detained and arrested with the consent of the Central Elections Commission.The new legislation prohibits the financing of presidential elections by foreign states, organizations, or private individuals.The adopted amendments require candidates for the lower chamber of the Tajik parliament to have lived in the country for the past five years. For the upper chamber, the requirement is seven years.Candidates to posts in the Tajik parliament can voluntarily leave the presidential race ten days before the election. In the previous legislation, the period was seven days.The next presidential election in Tajikistan will be held in fall 2020.ELECTIONSU.S. expects Azerbaijan toÂ hold fair election - diplomatBAKU. Feb 7 (Interfax) - U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian Affairs Bridget Brink hopes the early presidential election in Azerbaijan on April 11 will be free and just.Speaking at a news briefing in Baku on Wednesday, Brink said the United States favors free and just elections based on the Azerbaijani Constitution and international law.Brink refrained to comment on how the U.S. might react to incumbent President Ilham Aliyev's re-election, which experts are predicting.The next election was to be held on October 17. However, Aliyev signed a directive on moving the date up to April 11.Brink said she had also discussed the problem of Radio Azadliq, the Azerbaijani bureau of Radio Liberty, with Azerbaijani leaders during her Baku visit and would report the outcomes of these discussions to her superiors upon returning to Washington.Brink said she was not authorized to comment on the radio station's influence on Azerbaijan's media environment but maintained that the presence of different opinions there helps listeners obtain trustworthy information.Azerbaijani law enforcement agencies sealed the Radio Azadliq office in Baku in December 2014 over suspicions of embezzlement and money laundering.CURRENCY RATESOfficial exchange rates asÂ of 13.02.2018

column5: NEW DELHI,25th January, 2017 (WAM) -- In the presence of His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and Deputy Supreme Commander of the UAE Armed Forces, and India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the Abu Dhabi NationalOilCompany (ADNOC) and the Indian Strategic Petroleum Reserves Ltd (ISPRL), agreed on Wednesday to establish
column9: ADNOC signs agreement for 5.86m barrels strategic crude oil reserve in India
column10: NEW DELHI,25th January, 2017 (WAM) -- In the presence of His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and Deputy Supreme Commander of the UAE Armed Forces, and India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) and the Indian Strategic Petroleum Reserves Ltd (ISPRL), agreed on Wednesday to establisha strategic crude oil storage in the southern Indian city of Mangalore.The agreement with ISPRL, an Indian government-owned company mandated to store crude oil for emergency needs, covers the storage of 5.86 million barrels of ADNOC crude oil in underground facilities, at the Karnataka facility.Copies of the agreement, were exchanged by Dr Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber, UAE Minister of State and ADNOC Group CEO, and India's Petroleum Minister Dharmendra Pradhan, at a ceremony in New Delhi, during a visit to India by a high-ranking UAE delegation, led by HH Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed.Dr Al Jaber said: "This agreement, championed by the leadership of both countries, introduces a new strategic energy partnership with India that leverages the UAE and ADNOC's expertise and oil resources. This mutually beneficial partnership will create opportunities for ADNOC to increase its market share in delivering high quality crude to India's expanding refining industry, while also helping India meet its growing energy demand and safeguard its security.“India is an important energy market and this storage agreement reinforces ADNOC's role as one of the world's most trusted and reliable suppliers of oil. We will utilise the Mangalore facility to not only build on our existing business relationships across India but also to explore new downstream opportunities for ADNOC's expanding range of refined and petrochemical products,” he added.The Petroleum Minister of India, Dharmendra Pradhan, said: “It is our hope that this strategic agreement will build on the strong bonds of cooperation between our two nations and provide the foundation for a mutually beneficial energy partnership. This will also help to ensure India's energy security and enable us to meet the nation's growing demand for energy. This agreement is also a reflection of the vision of the Honourable Prime Minister of India towards strengthening hydrocarbon linkages with UAE in a win-win basis.”The Mangalore oil storage facility is the third that ADNOC has had access to in Asia. In Japan, the ADNOC has oil stored in the Kiire's Oil Terminal in Kagoshima City, and in South Korea a similar agreement allowed ADNOC to store oil in KNOC's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. In addition to helping to ensure energy security, the oil storage facilities enable ADNOC to efficiently and competitively meet market demand across south east Asia.India is 79 per cent dependent on imports to meet its crude oil needs, eight per cent of which is supplied by the UAE. In addition to the Mangalore facility, the ISPRL is building underground storage facilities at Visakhapatnam, in Andhra Pradesh, and Padur, in Karnataka, to stockpile 20 million barrels of oil, enough to meet India's oil requirement for 10 days.During the visit to India, Dr Al Jaber also signed a MoU to explore options to supply crude oil to West Bengal's Haldia Petrochemicals Ltd's (HPL) new refinery in Kolkata, which will have a consumption capacity of 300,000 barrels of oil per day.Under the terms of the MoU, ADNOC and HPL will also examine the possibility of ADNOC increasing the supply of light refined naphtha to HPL.Copyright 2017 by Emirates News Agency Distributed by UPICopyright of Arabia 2000 is the property of Arabia 2000.  The copyright in an individual article may be maintained by the author in certain cases.  Content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. However, users may print, download, or email articles for individual use. Source: Arabia 2000, Jan 25, 2017Item: 6FI1750300255

column5: ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Theoilrefining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries for 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes or 9% higher than in 2017, according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: Crude oil refining in Kazakhstan to grow 9% in 2018.
column10: OFFICIAL NEWSCrude oil refining in Kazakhstan to grow 9% in 2018ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ The oil refining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries for 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes or 9% higher than in 2017, according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday.In 2017 the domestic refineries processed 14.9 million tonnes of crude oil compared to the target of 14.5 million tonnes or an increase of 2.8% from 2016.The output of oil bitumen in 2018 is expected to amount to 740,000 tonnes.In 2017 Kazakhstan produced 731,000 tonnes of bitumen or an increase of 46.7% from 2016. Last year the republic exported 97,000 tonnes of bitumen to Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and China.There are three refineries in Kazakhstan: Atyrau, Pavlodar and Shymkent.OFFICIAL NEWSKazakhstan to implement 16 domestic gas supply projects worth 12.8 bln tenge in 2018ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Kazakhstan will implement 16 domestic gas supply projects in six regions of the country in 2018.â€œIn 2018 we will implement 16 domestic gas supply projects in six regions (Zhambyl, South Kazakhstan, Aktobe, Kyzylorda, West Kazakhstan and Almaty regions) for a total amount of 12.8 billion tenge,â€ according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday.The share of households that have access to domestic gas services will account for 47.65% in 2018 compared with 47.38% in 2017.The Energy Ministry of Kazakhstan set the sale gas production target for 2018 at 31.9 billion cubic meters.OFFICIAL NEWSKazakhstan in talks with Karachaganak stakeholder about construction of fourth refineryASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ The government of Kazakhstan is in talks with the Karachaganak stakeholders about construction of a fourth refinery, President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev said.â€œWe are modernizing all our three refineries. The shortage of gasoline will be covered in the next three-four years. Then we will have to import gasoline again. When I talked earlier about the urgent need to build a fourth refinery, I was told that we did not need it. We only start doing something when we are faced with a problem. I know that we all are working on this issue. We have had a talk with the Karachaganak investors. We need to speed up the decision-making on a [fourth] refinery,â€ Nazarbayev said at the extended meeting of the Kazakh government in Astana on Friday.The government of Kazakhstan is in talks with the Karachaganak stakeholders about production sharing calculations. The talks have been extended until the end of the 3rd quarter of 2018.One of the prerequisites for termination of the dispute about production sharing calculations may be construction of a production facility, which has yet to be decided upon.In April 2016, the Ministry of Energy said that there were certain controversial issues regarding the Karachaganak project that relate to production sharing calculations.The Financial Times said last year referring to people familiar with the situation that KPO had offered to pay about $300m to settle a dispute with the Kazakh government over the Karachaganak oil and gas field but the government had rejected the offer.Earlier last year some media quoted Lukoil as saying that Kazakhstan claimed about $1.6 billion from the Karachaganak partners under the production sharing agreement (PSA) on the Karachaganak field.Minister of Energy Kanat Bozumbayev said earlier that Kazakhstan would back out of the arbitration process if the government was satisfied with the dispute resolution proposal from the Karachaganak shareholders.The Karachaganak oil and gas condensate field is one of the largest in the world. Its reserves are estimated at 1.2 billion tonnes of oil and 1.35 trillion cubic meters of gas. It is operated by Karachaganak Petroleum Operating B.V., which is comprised of Shell (29.25%) (through its 100% affiliate company BG Karachaganak Ltd), Eni (29.25%), Chevron (18%), LUKOIL (13.5%), KazMunayGas (10%).OFFICIAL NEWSNational Bank to monitor banksâ€™ money flows - NazarbayevAlmaty. Feb 9(Interfax-Kazakhstan) - The President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev wants the government to speed up the legislative procedures necessary to adopt the bill authorizing the National Bank to monitor the fund flows in second-tier banks.â€œI've instructed to submit a bill that will empower the National Bank with the authority to monitor the ongoing money flows and financial performance of the banks to nip anything illegal in the bud. I ask you to speed up the adoption of the bill,â€ Nazarbayev said at a meeting government on Friday.OFFICIAL NEWSKazakhstan to triple cargo transportation to Turkish seaports in 2018ASTANA. Feb 7 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Cargo transportation from Kazakhstanâ€™s Aktau seaport to Turkish seaports reached 35,000 tonnes in 2017, Minister of Investment and Development Zhenis Kasymbek said.â€œThis year we expect to boost the volume of cargo transportation [from Aktau seaport to Turkish seaports] by 200%,â€ Kasymbek said at a Wednesday meeting of the Majilis, the lower chamber of the Kazakh parliament, in Astana.This year, Kazakhstan will start transportation of oversized equipment from the Black Sea and the Baltic Sea for construction of Tengizhchevroilâ€™s plant, the minister said.OFFICIAL NEWSSamruk-Kazyna not considering sale of its stake in KMG Kashagan B.V. to compensate for lossesASTANA. Feb 5 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna is not considering selling its stake in KMG Kashagan B.V. to compensate for Moldovan businessman Anatolie Stati's losses, Kazakhstan's legal dispute with whom has been ongoing for several years, the state fund has told Interfax-Kazakhstan.Samruk-Kazyna JSC was not a party to the arbitration proceedings between Kazakhstan and the plaintiffs [Anatolie Stati, Gabriel Stati, Ascom Group SA Terra Raf Trans Trading Ltd.] , the arbitral tribunal did not rule against Samruk-Kazyna regarding any payments to be made in favor of the plaintiffs and to this end Samruk-Kazyna "is not considering the sale of shares of KMG Kashagan BV", the state fund stated.Samruk-Kazyna said that the preliminary decision of Amsterdam-based court on January 5, 2018 to uphold the restrictions on management of KMG Kashagan B.V shares owned by the state fund does not restrict its rights.Samruk-Kazyna is in the process of informing its creditors.It reassures that the fund will continue to resolutely protect its rights and interests. "The fund does not expect events that could have a significant adverse impact on its financial stability," Samruk-Kazyna said to this end.In the last four years Kazakhstan has been involved in a series of court proceedings in connection with the arbitration proceedings initiated by Anatolie Stati, his son Gabriel Stati and their two companies Ascom Group S.A. and Terra Raf Trans Trading Ltd who filed a lawsuit claim of over $4 billion, according to Kazakhstan's Ministry of Justice.The court of Amsterdam froze $28 billion worth of Kazakhstan's assets after Anatolie Stati and his partners had filed a $500 million lawsuit against Kazakhstan for confiscation of oil projects in 2010.Earlier in December 2017 as part of this case nearly $22 billion of Kazakhstan's National Fund (40% of its total volume) was frozen by the Bank of New York Mellon Corp. In addition, earlier this month the news agency Bloomberg reported with reference to a statement by Anatolie Stati and his partners that Amsterdam-based court upheld the decision to freeze Samruk-Kazyna's stake in KMG Kashagan B.V. valued at $5.2 billion.In October 2015, State Fund Samruk-Kazyna acquired KazMunayGaz'50%-stake in the Kashagan project leaving the national company with the right to buy back shares in accordance with an option agreement.In January this year it became known that KazMunaiGaz extended for two years the buy-back option regarding this stake in Kashagan currently owned by Samruk-Kazyna. Under an additional agreement for the option agreement signed by Cooperatieve KazMunaiGaz U.A. (based in Netherlands and 98.88% KMG-owned ) and Samruk-Kazyna, the 2018-2020 option deadline was extended for a new period scheduled for 2020-22.Kashagan is Kazakhstanâ€™s first offshore oil and gas field in the Caspian Sea. It is the largest international investment project in the country. Oil commercial production at Kashagan started on November 1, 2016.Kashagan is developed by North Caspian Operating Company (NCOC) that is owned by KMG Kashagan B.V. (16.877%), Shell Kazakhstan Development B.V. (16.807%), Total EP Kazakhstan (16.807%), AgipCaspian Sea B.V. (16.807%), ExxonMobil Kazakhstan Inc. (16.807%), CNPC Kazakhstan B.V. (8.333%) and Inpex NorthCaspian Sea Ltd. (7.563%).OFFICIAL NEWSNazarbayev dismisses labor and social protection ministerASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev has dismissed Minister of Labor and Social Protection of the Population Tamara Duisenova, the presidential press office has said.By his decree the president appointed Madina Abylkasymova to this post, according to the press office.Earlier on Friday, at a government meeting Nazarbayev criticized the activity of the ministry led by Duisenova over the self-employed individuals.The president said at the meeting on Friday that the self-employed do not pay taxes, do not participate in the accumulative pension system, staying in the shadows though he repeatedly gave concrete instructions for at least five years on this matter but the problem was not dealt with.The president stressed that due to this problem the introduction of the mandatory social health insurance system was postponed in Kazakhstan.COMPANY NEWSKazMunayGas may come out with IPO in 2019ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ National Company KazMunayGas may hold IPO in 2019, according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday.â€œJSC National Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC and National Company KazMunayGas JSC expressed their intent in a joint letter dated June 6, 2017 to include the Atyrau refinery in the IPO of National Company KazMunayGas JSC. Taking into consideration this letter and the terms and conditions of the [privatization] program, National Company KazMunayGas JSC will supposedly hold IPO in 2019,â€ the document says.Minister of National Economy Timur Suleimenov told Interfax-Kazakhstan earlier that KazMunayGas will privatized as a vertically integrated holding company.National Company KazMunayGas JSC is a national operator for exploration, production, processing and transportation of hydrocarbons. The company represents the state interests in the oil and gas sector of Kazakhstan. KazMunayGas is owned by Samruk-Kazyna National Wealth Fund (90%) and by the National Bank of Kazakhstan (10%).COMPANY NEWSA fire at Pavlodar refinery led to shutdown of oil processing unitPAVLODAR. Feb 6 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Pavlodar Petrochemical Plant LLP, a refinery in the Pavlodar region, is looking into the cause of a fire in the pipeline of the crude distillation unit, the company says in a Monday press release.â€œOn February 3, 2018 at 1:33 pm the pipeline of crude distillation unit LK-6U at Pavlodar Petrochemical Plant caught fire. The unit was shut down immediately. The other units in the shop were not affected by the fire,â€ the press release says.Nobody was injured by the fire, the company said.The cause of the fire will be announced after the investigation is over, according to the press release.Repairs of the damaged pipeline are now underway.The crude distillation unit will be returned into operation on February 8 and all processing units of the refinery will resume normal operation from February 11, according to the press release.However, the refinery continues to ship petroleum products as usual from its stock.The incident will not affect the supply of petroleum products in the domestic market, the company said.There are three refineries in Kazakhstan: the Shymkent refinery, which is owned by KazMunayGas and CNPC on a parity basis, the Atyrau and Pavlodar refineries, which are controlled by KazMunayGas.COMPANY NEWSMoody's assigns B2 rating to Nostrum's proposed notesALMATY. Feb 6 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Moody's Investors Service (Moody's) assigned a B2 rating with a loss given default assessment of LGD4 to the proposed senior unsecured notes to be issued by Nostrum Oil & Gas Finance B.V., a wholly owned subsidiary of Nostrum Oil & Gas Plc (Nostrum), the rating agency says in a press release.Concurrently, Moody's affirmed Nostrum's B2 corporate family rating (CFR), B2-PD probability of default rating (PDR) and the B2 senior unsecured ratings assigned to the notes issued by Nostrum's wholly owned subsidiaries Zhaikmunai LLP and Nostrum Oil & Gas Finance B.V.The outlook on the ratings remains negative.â€œThe B2 rating assigned to the proposed notes is the same as Nostrum's CFR, which reflects Moody's view that these notes will rank pari passu with Nostrum's existing notes. The proposed notes will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed by Nostrum Oil & Gas Plc and certain of its subsidiaries, including the group's core operating company Zhaikmunai LLP,â€ the press release says.The negative outlook on Nostrum's ratings captures elevated leverage as well as the risks related to the timely launch of the GTU 3 facility and execution of the drilling program allowing full utilization of GTU 3 despite a pick-up in oil prices over the last several months, according to Moodyâ€™s.â€œThe outlook could be stabilized if Moody's were to see stabilization of production during 2018 provided that the company remains on track with its drilling program and launches GTU 3 in 2018,â€ the press release says.Similar to Nostrum's existing $725 million notes due 2022, the proposed notes will be issued by Nostrum Oil & Gas Finance B.V., a private company incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands, which is wholly owned by Nostrum Oil & Gas Cooperatief U.A., a 100%-owned subsidiary of Nostrum Oil & Gas Plc.The notes will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed on a senior basis by, inter alia, Zhaikmunai LLP, the group's sole operating subsidiary, which owns substantially all of the group's assets, according to Moodyâ€™s.Zhaikmunai is an independent oil and gas enterprise currently engaging in the exploration, production and sale of crude oil and gas condensate in northwestern Kazakhstan. Zhaikmunai's main producing asset is the Chinarevskoye field located in the northern part of the oil-rich Pre-Caspian Basin.PIPELINES AND TRANSPORTATIONNord Stream 2 AG may claim damages if EU Gas Directive extended to import pipelinesMOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Nord Stream 2 AG may claim damages it the European Union's Gas Directive is extended to import pipelines, the company's managing director, Matthias Warnig, said in an interview with the WirtschaftsWoche publication in Germany.Presently, the EU Gas Directive applies only to the domestic markets of EU member states. The European Commission, in its turn, is demanding a say on matters concerning the pipeline."I do not understand how extending the Gas Directive beyond the EU will work," Warnig said. "If EU terms lead to negative fallout for us, the issue of claiming damages will be raised," he said.EU terms may lead to a change in company ownership. According to current European legislation, one entity cannot be both the owner and operator of a pipeline. Gazprom is the sole shareholder of Nord Stream 2 and its operator. The pipeline is being financed by Gazprom and five foreign companies: Uniper, Shell, Wintershall, OMV and Engie.Denmark should consider Russia's application for the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline based on the laws valid in the European Union at the moment of its submission, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Tuesday."We addressed the consideration by Denmark of the application for building the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in the kingdom's territorial waters. We highlighted our principled position that this application must be considered based on the laws existing both in Denmark and in the European Union in general as of the moment when this application was submitted," Lavrov said following negotiations with Danish Foreign Minister Anders Samuelsen.The application in question was submitted in April 2017, Lavrov said.PIPELINES AND TRANSPORTATIONSovcomflot fines USC's Finnish shipyard for delay on Sakhalin-2 vessels - paperMOSCOW. Feb 5 (Interfax) - Sovcomflot (SCF), Russia's largest shipping company, has fined Arctech Helsinki Shipyard, a division of United Shipbuilding Corporation (USC), for holding up delivery of four support vessels for the Sakhalin-2 oil and gas project, national daily Kommersant reported on Monday.The shipyard was late delivering all four vessels: supply ship Gennady Nevelskoi and standby vessels Stepan Makarov, Fyodor Ushakov and Yevgeny Primakov, which will operate under a long-term charter contract for Sakhalin Energy.The companies did not disclose the amount of the fines. USC president Alexei Rakhmanov said that the initial fines were reduced by 30% for three vessels and by 70% for the Yevgeny Primakov, the delay for which "was about seven months and was related exclusively to the imposition of sanctions on USC."SCF declined to comment, the paper said. "Initially the amount of fines was simply astronomical, but in the end it amounted to about $50 million," the paper reported a source as saying.The Finnish shipyard had a particularly difficult time in 2015, when it was left without financing. After Crimea became part of Russia and sanctions were imposed against a number of Russian companies, including USC, western banks refused to work with Arctech. Only after a year did USC manage to secure a forex loan from Sberbank to complete the orders. At the end of 2016, the corporation refinanced $435 million at state bank VTB at 4.5% annual interest."The contract only had a 20% advance, so we had to look for 80% ourselves," Rakhmanov was reported as saying by the paper.But the shipyard's financial problems are not confined to the SCF fines. Construction of the Project 21900M Murmansk icebreaker for Rosmorport was paralysed in Helsinki in 2015 for the same reason."We're not as worried about losses from the construction of the series, as we are by the matter with the icebreaker. Before we got full control of the shipyard, it was contracted by our Finnish colleagues in rubles with a 60% share of foreign components. As a result, we get an exchange rate difference that no one has compensated," Rakhmanov said. The loss amounted to about half the price of the icebreaker, he said.USC is now trying to bring orders for cruise ships with displacement of up to 75,000 tonnes to its Finnish shipyard. "We have preliminary talks with Japanese customers. A Chinese operating company is also interested," Rakhmanov said.Considering the finance losses in recent years, Arctech will not earn a profit in the next seven years, so a financial recovery through bankruptcy is a possibility, he said.
