This is how USC sorted out the debts of Baltiysky Zavod, which was split into two legal entities that were merged only recently.However, USC is hoping for support from Kermas Group, with which negotiations are being held to sell a controlling stake in Arctech. The group owns Croatian shipyard Brodotrogir, which a year ago laid the fore part of a tanker to carry gas condensate that was ordered from Arctech for the Yamal LNG project. Kermas hopes to boost utilization of capacity at the Croatian shipyard by working on orders placed with Arctech.PIPELINES AND TRANSPORTATIONTurkmenistan, Turkey's Calyk sign memorandum to build power lines along TAPIASHGABAT. Feb 1 (Interfax) - Turkmenistan's Energy Ministry and Turkish company Calyk Holding A.S. have signed a memorandum of understanding on the implementation of a project to build power transmission lines across Turkmenistan, Afghanistan and Pakistan.Turkmenistan's state news agency said that the 500 kW voltage power lines will be built along the route of the Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan-India (TAPI) transnational gas pipeline.The construction of the power lines, as well as providing electricity supply to TAPI infrastructure facilities, will allow for exports via Afghanistan to Pakistan and other south-east Asian countries, the governments of which have previously announced their interest in the rapid implementation of the project.Substations and 500 kW overhead power lines have already built to increase electricity exports from Turkmenistan to Afghanistan.A number of measures are scheduled to start on February 23, 2018 these include the start of construction of the Afghan section of TAPI, the laying of a fiber-optic communications link along the route of the pipeline, the start of construction of the Turkmenistan-Afghanistan-Pakistan power lines and the launch ceremony for the Serhatabat-Tourghundi railway between Turkmenistan and Afghanistan. Construction of the entire pipeline is due to be completed by the end of 2019,PIPELINES AND TRANSPORTATIONEIB Board approves EUR 1.5 bln loan for Trans-Adriatic Pipeline projectBAKU. Feb 7 (Interfax) - The European Investment Bank's Board of Directors has approved loan of 1.5 billion euros loan for construction of the Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP), the bank said in a statement."At its first meeting of 2018 on February 6, the EIB approved extension of 1.5 billion euros in financing for construction of the TAP pipeline," the statement said.Overall, the board at its meeting approved a total of 6.5 billion euros of new financing for 36 projects in 17 European Union countries and schemes in Africa, Asia and Latin America.TAP is part of the Southern Gas Corridor project to set up pipeline infrastructure to supply Azerbaijani gas to Europe.Initial capacity will be 10 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year with the possibility of doubling this.The TAP project is designed to transport natural gas from Azerbaijan's Shah Deniz field as part of stage 2 of its development via Greece and Albania to Western Europe. TAP will run for 550 km in northern Greece, 215 km in Albania, 105 km across the Adriatic Sea and 8 km in Italy. TAP shares are divided between State Oil Company of the Azerbaijani Republic (SOCAR) (20%), BP (20%), Snam (20%), Fluxys (19%), Enagas (16%) and Axpo (5%).CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSRussian oil export duty increases by $8.7 to $120.1/tonne on Feb 1MOSCOW. Feb 1 (Interfax) - Russia's export duty on oil increased by $8.7 to $120.1 per tonne on February 1, 2017, according to Economic Development Ministry data.The export duty was $111.4 per tonne in January.The discounted export duty for oil from Eastern Siberia, Caspian fields and the Prirazlomnoye field re-mains at zero due to the new calculation formula adopted as part of the tax maneuver in the oil industry.The duty on high viscosity oil rose to $19.5 per tonne in February from $17.9 in January.The duty on light oil products and lubricants increased to $36 from $33.4 per tonne, and the duty on dark oil products rose to $120.1 from $111.4 per tonne.The export duties on commercial gasoline grew to $36 from $33.4 a tonne and on straight-run gasoline (naphtha) to $66 from $61.2 per tonne.The duty on liquefied gas remains at zero.The duty on coke, and on trimers and tetramers, increased to $7.8 from $7.2 per tonne.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSRussian oil cos, Energy Ministry to continue monitoring OPEC+ situationMOSCOW. Feb 6 (Interfax) - Russia's oil companies and the Energy Ministry will continue monitoring the situation with the OPEC+ deal, Lukoil President Vagit Alekperov told reporters following a meeting of the heads of the major oil companies and the ministry."Simply to continue monitoring, then the minister will decide," he said.Russia's budget will receive an additional $50 billion due to the deal with OPEC, Alekperov said."We didn't discuss anything more. The task was to discuss OPEC, and we agreed to monitor the situation and then see," said Alexander Fridman, first deputy CEO of Novatek.Surgutneftegas chief Vladimir Bogdanov also gave a favorable assessment to the OPEC+ deal. "Positive," Bogdanov said when asked about his response to the deal.The agreement for OPEC countries to lower by daily output by 1,21 million barrels and non-OPEC countries by 558,000 bpd compared to October 2016 levels went into effect on January 1, 2017. In late May 2017, the countries agreed to extend the deal for nine months until March 31, 2018 and in November 2017 they extended it through the end of 2018, leaving its conditions unchanged. The purpose of the deal is to lower global oil inventories to levels corresponding to their five-year average.The development of Russian oil refining and the quality of crude pumped along Transneft's pipelines was also discussed during the meeting between the oil companies and the Energy Ministry. The oil pipeline monopoly's vice president, Sergei Andronov, told Interfax in an interview in November that the level of high-sulfur crude supply using the Transneft system will total 87.5 million tonnes in 2018, 88 million tonnes in 2019 and 88.5 million tonnes in 2020."We can see three main reasons for the changing quality of crude in the system. The first is without doubt an increase in supply of highly sulfurous oil into the Transneft system, which was 5 million tonnes in the period 2014-2017. The second is a reduction in high-sulfur crude throughput at Russian refineries of 4.5 million tonnes in the same period. But the main factor is the planned re-routing of 12 million tonnes of crude, starting in 2018, from West to East, in connection with the need to honor contracts signed in fulfillment of inter-governmental agreements between Russia and China," Andronov said. It is for the profile ministry to reach a decision on this.The discussion of ways to stimulate the oil refining industry is still at an early stage and a meeting with cabinet ministers is planned for the last ten days of February, Lukoil chief Vagit Alekperov told reporters following the meeting between oil companies and the Energy Ministry."The budget benefits to the tune of $50 billion from the participation of oil companies in the OPEC+ deal, and that could stimulate oil refining," he said."Lukoil's position on refining is still to keep the export duty in place in the medium term. That will make it possible to complete all refinery upgrades," he said.Oil companies have been complaining about low oil refining margins in Russia. The Energy Ministry has been given instructions to work out measures to support the refining industry. One calls for introduction a negative excise tax on crude oil that a company supplies to its own refineries in Russia to produce gasoline and aviation kerosene. The size of the excise would depend on the production volume of these fuel types.The Finance Ministry insists that proposals to introduce the negative excise tax on crude oil be tied in with the need to abolish export duty on oil. Both ministries plan to finalize their proposals to stimulate refining before the end of March.Apart from Lukoil's Alekperov, the meeting on Tuesday was due to be attended by Pavel Fyodorov, first vice president of Rosneft; Surgutneftegas chief Vladimir Bogdanov; Vadim Yakovlev, first deputy head of Gazprom Neft; Maxim Grishanin, first vice president of Transneft; Zarubezhneft head Sergei Kudryashov; Novatek first deputy CEO Alexander Fridman; Tatneft deputy head Azat Yagafarov; and RussNeft owner Mikhail Gutseriev.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSGazprom could raise gas output to 476 bcm in 2018 from 471 bcm in 2017MOSCOW. Feb 6 (Interfax) â€“ Gazprom held its latest Investor Day in New York on Tuesday. Company officials told investors the Russian gas giant is planning to produce 476 billion cubic meters of gas in 2018, following the 471 bcm it produced in 2017. They said Gazprom raised its share of the European gas market to 34.7% in 2017 from 33.1% in 2016. Gazprom revised its estimate for natural gas exports to non-FSU countries in 2017 to 194.4 billion cubic meters, and said that Ukraine's gas transmission system remains functional only because it is not loaded to capacity. Gazprom announced it has so far built 1,480 kilometers of the 2,158-km linear section of kits Power of Siberia gas pipeline and had laid around 800 km of the two TurkStream lines by the beginning of February. Gazprom said it expects annual investment to stabilize at the level 1 trillion rubles or lower once the record investment in 2018 and 2019 (1.4 trillion rubles) has passed.PRODUCTION: Another year of growthGazprom is planning to produce 476 billion cubic meters of gas in 2018, following the 471 bcm it produced in 2017, the head of Gazprom's Department 307, Vsevolod Cherepanov, said at a meeting with investors in New York."Actual gas production in 2017 was 471 bcm, which was 52 bcm more than in 2016. Most of the gas was produced at fields in the Nadym-Pur-Tazovsky district - 348 bcm. The gas production plan for 2018 is 476 bcm," Cherepanov said.Gazprom produced 82.7 bcm at the Bovanenkovo field on the Yamal Peninsula, above a targeted 76.7 bcm.EXPORTS: Market share growingGazprom revised its estimate for natural gas exports to non-FSU countries in 2017 to 194.4 billion cubic meters from 193.9 bcm previously."The year 2017 was a special one for Gazprom. Last year our company set an absolute record for gas exports to Europe in the whole history of the Soviet and Russian gas industry, supplying 194.4 bcm of gas. This is about one-fourth of all the cross-border trade in pipeline gas worldwide," Medvedev said.Gazprom exported 179.3 bcm of gas in 2016.Medvedev said the average export price of Gazprom's gas last year was $196.7 per thousand cubic meters. This was $224 per thousand cubic meters of $6.4 per MBtu in January this year, and the forecast for February is $221 per thousand cubic meters, $6.29 per MBtu.Gazprom exported 17.2 billion cubic meters (bcm) of gas to non-FSU countries in January 2018, Gazprom's information department reported.The total is 1.9 bcm or 10% less than in January 2017, "which was the highest monthly volume in the company's history," it said.The decline was largely due to warm weather in European countries, Gazprom said."That said, the total for January 2018 was 2.1 bcm or 13.9% more than in January 2016 and 13.8% more than the average in 2015-2017," the company said.Average temperatures in Europe were warmer in January 2018 than a year earlier by approximately 4 degrees Celsius. Interfax Global Gas Analytics also notes lower demand for gas in Europe from the power generation sector, which competes with other energy sources, particularly renewable energy.Another reason for the export slowdown is the increase in the price of gas calculated using the formula in long-term Gazprom supply contracts, which is tied to the price of oil. That price increased 20% to $237 per 1,000 cubic meters in January 2018, up from $198 in January 2017, according to data published by the Federal Antimonopoly Service (FAS).In other words, Gazprom's contract price is now nearly equal and perhaps higher than the spot price, which limits the appeal of Russian gas.Given the increase in the export price, revenue from the exports rose approximately 8% in January 2018 year-on-year (based on the calculated contract price).Meanwhile, gas inventories in European underground storage only fell below the 50% mark on January 30 or 8 percentage points higher than on the same day last year. Larger inventories at the end of the heating season will reduce demand for gas to replenish the storage facilities which, together with the price level, could negatively impact Gazprom exports this summer.Gazprom produced 45.6 bcm of gas in January 2018, 3.2% less than in January 2017 but 7.4% more (3.1 bcm more) than in January 2016.EuropeGazprom raised its share of the European gas market to 34.7% in 2017 from 33.1% in 2016, Gazprom in a presentation."As natural gas consumption on the European market increases, Gazprom's market share is also increasing robustly. Gazprom's supplies once again grew faster than the market in 2017, increasing our market share to a record 34.7%," said Gazprom CEO Alexander Medvedev.Norway also succeeded in increasing gas supplies last year. Britain [increased production slightly but] did not increase exports. The drop in supply from the Dutch Groningen field to the European market was offset mainly by supplies from Gazprom, Medvedev said.Kirill Polous, head of the Russian gas giant's Department 123, said: "In keeping with the latest long-term forecasts by leading analytical agencies [IHS Markit and Wood Mackenzie], the share of has supplied by Gazprom could be 35%-38% by 2030 and rise to 38%-41% by 2035. Such forecasts show that not only Gazprom, but also foreign analysts acknowledge that Russian pipeline gas is highly competitive compared to LNG."ChinaGazprom may capture 10% of the China's natural gas market by 2025 and supply 13% of the nation's gas needs by 2035, Polous saidThe Chinese market is the most dynamically developing market from the standpoint of both production and consumption, Polous said."That said, the prospective level of gas production in China is marked by a high degree of uncertainty, primarily due to the potential of shale gas production. Even in the event of significant successes in production of non-traditional gas in the country, which is not likely in current conditions, gas consumption in China will significantly outpace growth of domestic output, leading to further growth in gas imports," he said.Forecasts by leading industry analysts put the difference between China's consumption and domestic production of gas, including shale gas, at 200-280 billion cubic meters by 2035."Presently, we have yet to export gas to China via pipeline, but by 2025, we will be supplying around 10% of the country's consumption, just accounting for shipments under the 'Eastern route' contract. I will recall that the contract envisages annual shipments of 38 million cubic meters of Russia gas to China via the Power of Siberia pipeline, with the first gas due to be shipped less than two years from now, in December of 2019. We don't plan to stop at that and we are currently working with our Chinese partners on new pipeline projects, implementation of which will allow us to increase the presence of Gazprom's gas in China, and as per our expectations, capture 13% of the Chinese natural gas market by 2035," Polous said.Medvedev said in his Investor Day remarks that China had raised its 2017 natural gas imports 27% to 95 billion cubic meters, becoming the world's second largest gas importer. Some analysts believe that China may even outpace Japan as the leader in gas imports. According to CNPC estimates, China's gas imports from 2025 to 2030 will grow to 200 billion cubic meters, with an even more ambitious forecast by the Development Research Center of the State Council of China envisaging import growth to 300 billion cubic meters by 2030."Keeping in mind stable growth in demand for natural gas in China, as well as our unique logistical and resource advantages, we are optimistic not only about Russian gas shipments via the Power of Siberia pipeline, but also regarding the implementation prospects of projects envisaging gas shipments to China from the Russian Far East and via the 'Western route'," Medvedev said.Gazprom management is confident that negotiations with China on gas supplies from Russia's Far East will go more quickly than negotiations on the first Russian-Chinese gas contract, for supplies along the 'Western Route.'"Work on this contract is going very intensively. A document on the main conditions of this contract was signed quite recently. Taking into account the situation on the Chinese market, the Chinese side is interested in implementing this contract as soon as possible," Medvedev said.Speaking about specific timeframes for when exports will begin along this route, he used the usual qualification. "There is a standard commercial period from when a contract is signed to the start of supplies via pipeline transport. We simply use the rule that before you start extracting gas you first need to sell it. As soon as the price terms are agreed, we will announce a timeframe for the start of supplies," Medvedev said."And I'm confident that in this case the negotiations will take far less time than last time," Medvedev said.UkraineUkraine's gas transmission system remains functional only because it is not loaded to capacity, Medvedev said."Unfortunately, in supplying our European clients, we [have to] rely on the Ukrainian gas transport system. Gazprom's position on the reliability of this route is shared by international experts, including specialists from the Mott MacDonald consulting company. According to their calculations, Ukraine needs to invest $4.8 billion in the system over seven years. In fact, Kyiv is investment only 14%-20% of that figure. In that regard, the Ukrainian corridor can only function because it is loaded at less than 100%," he said.Gazprom is consistently conducting a strategy of minimizing transit risks, building new, state-of-the-art gas pipelines and selling additional volumes to our European customers. So, under the Nord Stream 1 project, Gazprom concluded new contracts to supply 20 bcm of gas. The new gas pipeline projects also provide such an ability," he said.Gazprom is satisfied with the price that Naftogaz Ukrainy must pay for gas as determined by Stockholm arbitration, Medvedev said.Gazprom will be ready to supply gas once it receives advance payment, he said.U.S.: LNG, sanctionsLNG exportsGazprom does not see U.S. liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a competitor to its pipeline gas supplies on the European market in the medium- or long-term future, Polous said."They have been frightening us for several years with the loss of market positions in Europe, but in the end 2017 closed with another record for exports of Russian pipeline gas and 2018 began with shipments of Russian LNG to the United States (as a result of re-exports from the UK). And we never saw an influx of American LNG into Europe," Polous said."Many of you begin your morning with a cup of coffee. If you compare the volume of Gazprom supplies to the European market to a cup of coffee, supplies of American LNG amount to just a few drops. Obviously, a few drops of coffee are unlikely to wake you up. Just like LNG from the U.S. has not had a significant impact on the diversification of gas supplies and energy security of the European region," Polous said at the meeting with investors, which began at 9:00 a.m. local time.A slide in his presentation contrasted Gazprom's "cup" with three drops under a magnifying glass to illustrate U.S. LNG exports to Europe.He also said that "even these negligible amounts of LNG were supplied primarily to countries that did not have access to Russian pipeline gas or the ability to increase supplies of it were limited.""We also don't expect competition with American LNG on the European market in the long term. Both the high cost of these supplies and our partners' interest in new gas transport pipelines for importing Russian gas into Europe speaks to this," Polous said.Since shipments began from the Sabine Pass LNG terminal in the U.S., a little more than 3 billion cubic meters of U.S. gas have been shipped, while Gazprom has delivered more than 350 bcm to its customers in this period, Medvedev said in his report."And even if you use the analogy of adding not coffee, but cognac to coffee, you would still be unlikely to detect the taste of cognac," Medvedev said, picking up on the previous speaker's analogy."When looking at the price of futures contracts on the TTF to 2022, it's apparent that, according to the current expectations of market players, the full cost of American LNG, taking into account toll payments, will remain significantly higher than the price of gas in Europe. This does not mean that we won't see new volumes of LNG from the U.S. in Europe in future, but presenting American LNG as a game changer on the European market today, at the very least, seems hasty, to put it mildly," Medvedev said.SanctionsThe latest U.S. sanctions law, Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA), does not apply to Gazprom export projects that are already in implementation, Gazprom said.In addition, less than 1% of Gazprom production falls under U.S. sectoral technology sanctions, according to the presentation."In August 2017, a law on new sanctions against Russia went into effect in the United States that, among other things, gives the U.S. president the right to impose sanctions against foreign persons who invest in Russian export pipeline projects. However, according to additional official clarifications from the U.S. authorities, projects that began to be implemented before the signing of the law, in other words before August 2, 2017, do not fall under its scope. Therefore, we on our part do not see a significant threat to our current business in connection with sanctions," Kruglov said.He said Gazprom is subject to "one of the mildest versions of sanctions compared to other Russian state companies." The group's head company, PJSC Gazprom "does not fall under U.S. and EU financial sanctions" and is "successfully working on the international capital market," Kruglov said."Furthermore, we have created a system of control and guarantees that excludes the possibility of using funds raised by Gazprom on international financial markets for the purpose of financing persons and companies subject to sanctions, including Gazprom Neft and Gazprombank," Kruglov said.The technology sanctions imposed against Russia's fuel and energy sector, which prohibit the transfer of technology for production in the Arctic, the deepwater shelf and from shale deposits, affect less than one percent of the group's production, he estimated. "All of these projects at the Gazprom group are not key and involve less than 1% of our production," Kruglov said.PIPELINES: Progress across the boardPower of SiberiaGazprom has so built 1,480 kilometers of the 2,158-km linear section of kits Power of Siberia gas pipeline, Kirill Polous, head of the Russian gas giant's Department 123, said.This is more than two-thirds of the pipeline, which will run from the Chayanda field in Yakutia to the Chinese border, construction of which began in 2014 and which will be capable of exporting 38 bcm of gas per year, Polous said."We built more than 900 km in 2017 alone, beating our original construction schedule by far," he said.Nord Stream 2The board of directors of project company Nord Stream 2 AG said last week that the project is fully on schedule and will be launched at the end of 2019, Gazprom Medvedev said."Obstacles to the project as of today are hypothetical in nature. We know all these risks. These are all hypothetical obstacles. I refer to the new Danish law that could theoretically be used to deny issuance of a permit for construction of the gas pipeline in Danish territorial waters," he said."We are not holding a legal seminar, in order to discuss the legality of passage of such a law, the theoretical application of such a law, whether it accords with EU standards. But, the fact there are political attempts to affect the project, this is well-known," Medvedev said."We proceed on the assumption that reason will prevail and the project will be implemented in all its parts: design, procurement, supply, in full accordance with the schedule," Medvedev said.The economic effect of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project on Gazprom's free cash flow and EBITDA could significantly exceed $1 billion per year thanks to complete consolidation and lower transport costs, the Russian gas giant's deputy CEO, Andrei Kruglov said at Investor Day in New York.He recalled that the cost of transporting the same amount of gas through Ukraine exceeds $1.5 billion per year.With the complete consolidation of the pipeline project in Gazprom's financial statements, expenditure items will not reflect the full rate charged, only far lower operating costs, while the investment component in the rate will be replaced by a noncash expenditure item, amortization, Kruglov said."In terms of generating EBITDA and free cash flow, the investment component will be equal to zero. The component generating profit will be equal to zero. The difference in the full amount will go toward increasing key financial indicators and Gazprom's cash flow," Kruglov said.TurkStreamGazprom expects a similar effect, through smaller in scale, from the TurkStream project.Polous said Gazprom had already laid around 800 km of the two TurkStream lines by the beginning of February.TurkStream will consist of two offshore pipelines, both with capacity to transport up to 15.75 billion cubic meters of natural gas per year or 31.5 bcm in total. The offshore section runs approximately 930 kilometers through the Black Sea, from the Russian city of Anapa to the Turkish town of KiyikÃ¶y. Gas transported via the first pipeline is destined for the Turkish market. The other pipeline will be directed towards the Turkish-European border. Work on the offshore section began on May 7, 2017.FINANCES: Investment stabilityGazprom expects annual investment to stabilize at the level 1 trillion rubles or lower once the record investment in 2018 and 2019 (1.4 trillion rubles) has passed.Investment is projected to fall below 1 trillion rubles in 2020 and then rise to about 1.1 trillion rubles a year in 2021-2025. Further on, in the final five years of the 2020s, annual investment is forecast at about 900 billion rubles (according to slides used in the presentation) and to about 800 billion rubles in 2031-2035."The fact that all three of our megaprojects will be launched at the end of next year accounts for the historically large volume of annual investment over the nearest two years - in the gas business, it will exceed the 'psychological milestone' of one trillion rubles," said Kirill Polous, head of the Russian gas giant's Department 123. "However, the substantial capital that we will invest in this period is a guarantee of the effective and stable growth of the company in the long term, significant growth in volume of gas output and export," Polous said."Going forward, we expect a gradual reduction in the investment burden. In the period to 2035 the annual average demand for investment will not exceed one trillion rubles. This guidance reflects demand for investment in projects which are presently being implemented [the speaker's slides featured Chayanda, Kovytka, Power of Siberia, TurkStream, and the Amur GPP] as well as a series of projects on which no final investment decision has yet been made [Baltic LNG, expansion of Sakhalin-2 and others]," he said."By 2035, implementation of these projects will allow us to increase output and exports 35% compared with 2016 levels," he said.OIL: Gazprom Neft's strong statisticsGazprom boosted oil production by more than 4% last year, Kruglov said.In listing the factors for further company growth, he said: "Intensive growth in the oil and gas business, the outlook for future growth. In 2017 as a whole, gas production rose more than 12% and oil more than 4%."Gazprom's oil business is concentrated in a subsidiary, Gazprom Neft.Gazprom Neft boosted net profit tentatively 45.3% in 2017 to $4.3 billion, the oil company said in materials for an Investor Day presentation by parent company Gazprom.Sales revenue grew 35.7% to $34 billion and EBITDA rose 38.7% to $9.4 billion rubles.Gazprom Neft's progress toward the goal of producing 100 million tonnes of oil will be adjusted somewhat by the OPEC+ agreement to curb oil production, but on the whole this target is achievable, the Russian oil company's CFO, Alexei Yankevich said at Gazprom's Investor Day.Profit predictionsGazprom Neft expects its net profit to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) rose 26.5% in 2017 to 253 billion rubles, the oil producer said in a statement.Sales revenue might have grown more than 18% to 2 trillion rubles."This growth in key financial metrics in 2017 is due to improved market conditions, the successful development of new initiatives in hydrocarbon production and in increasing retail sales, and effective management initiatives," the company said."Improved operating cash flow and the completion of key infrastructure investments at new upstream projects resulted in free cash flow increasing to 65 billion rubles in 2017," it said.Last year "was a record financial year for Gazprom Neft, with the company achieving the highest net profit in its history," said Alexander Dyukov, its CEO. "The company's operating cash flow throughout last year stood at 422 billion rubles, another record," he said.EBITDA could have grown 20.8% to 551 billion rubles and free cash flow of 65 billion rubles is anticipated for 2017.Gazprom Neft plans to maintain capital expenditure to 2020 at roughly last year's level, Kruglov said."Gazprom's oil business [represented by Gazprom Neft] is developing dynamically. Gazprom Neft has passed through the peak period of investment in production projects. Such major projects as Prirazlomnoye and Novoportovskoye have already been launched. That said, plans are to maintain capital investment at roughly last year's level, and key projects will be associated with modernization of refining capacity," he said.Gazprom Neft's investment program totaled 385 billion rubles in 2017 and is at the same level in 2018."In the oil business, which contributes over 25% of EBITDA, Gazprom Neft is in the middle of the growth cycle and, in our opinion, is the best growth story in the history of the Russian oil industry," Kruglov said.New projectsGazprom Neft calculates that its new projects, upon reaching peak production, will provide a combined total of up to 28 million tonnes of oil a year, the oil major said in materials presented during Investor Day at parent company Gazprom.Gazprom Neft does not provide a schedule of production from the new projects, which are currently at varying stages of study and development.On average, Gazprom Neft is expecting to launch commercial production within new projects in 2018-2024. The Yamburg project, where the license is held by Gazprom and Gazprom Neft is the operator, is slated to begin production in 2023, with peak production of 6 million tonnes; the Tazovsky (Tazov) block and Severo-Samburgskoye (North Samburg) deposits in 2021 with peak production of 1 million tonnes at each of the deposits; the group of remote deposits in 2018 with a peak of 2 million tonnes; the Chonsky (Chon) project in 2024 with peak production of 6 million tonnes; and the Zapadno-Zimneye (West Zimneye) field in 2020 with a peak of 2 million tonnes. Gazprom Neft will begin production at SPD's Southern hub as part of its JV with Shell in 2020 with peak production of 2 million tonnes and will launch production at Evrotek-Yugra fields within its JV with Repsol the same year with peak production of 3 million tonnes.The new offshore project, the Ayashsky (Ayash) block, within which the company discovered the large Neptune oil deposit, is expected to launch commercial production in 2027, with peak production of 6 million tonnes. Earlier information suggested that Gazprom Neft is planning to prepare a detailed estimate of oil reserves at the Neptune deposit by mid-2018 and continue follow-up exploration only in 2019. Existing road maps envisage production at the Netune deposit beginning in 2025-2027.Gazprom Neft has also posted production figures for large new projects already launched. Thus, production at the Prirazlomnoye field in 2017 was 53,000 barrels per day (bpd), with a 2018 forecast of 72,000 bpd and a 2019 forecast of 83,000 bpd. The Novoport field produced 120,000 bpd in 2017, with forecasts of 137,000 bpd in 2018 and 159,000 bpd in 2019. Output at Messoyakha in 2017 was 63,000 bpd, with forecasts of 88,000 bpd for 2018 and 109,000 bpd for 2019.ReservesGazprom Neft had PRMS reserves totaling 2.781 billion tonnes of oil equivalent at the end of 2017, 2.2% more than a year earlier, according to materials presented at Investor Day.Probable PRMS reserves increased 4.48% to 1.259 billion tonnes of oil equivalent and proved reserves were up 0.5% to 1.522 billion tonnes.Hydrocarbon production increased 4.1% in 2016 to 89.8 million tonnes of oil equivalent.Refining declined 4.2% to 40.1 million tonnes.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSUkrnaftoburinnia seeks to increase drilling to six new wells in 2018KYIV. Feb 1 (Interfax) - Private joint-stock company Ukrnaftoburinnia, which is among top three largest private gas producers in the country, plans to drill at least six new wells in 2018 compared with four drilled in 2017, the company's press service reported on Wednesday.Ukrnaftoburinnia Head Mykhailo Bakunenko said that the company plans to boost pro-duction by 40-50% in 2018. Last year the efficient level of production at wells that were placed to the idle fund or were inefficient was restored.Gas production by the company in 2017 grew by 50.6% or 131 million cubic meters com-pared with 2016, to 390 million cubic meters. Production of oil and gas condensate rose by 48.3% or 14,000 tonnes, to 43,000 tonnes.Gas sales by the company grew to 850 million cubic meters compared with 445 million cubic meters in 2016. Sales of oil and condensate increased to 48,500 tonnes compared with 32,400 tonnes.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSWinner of tender to use Odesa Port-Side Plant on tolling basis not supplying enough gas, debt to Ukrtransgaz growingKYIV. Feb 5 (Interfax) - All-Ukrainian Energo Company LLC, which won a tender to use the production facilities of Odesa Port-Side Plant on a tolling basis, is not supplying enough gas for operations to the chemical enterprise, Ukrtransgaz, the operator of the Ukrainian gas transport system (GTS), reported."On January 25, 2017, Ukrtransgaz received a monthly application (nominated in January) from the customer for the services of All-Ukrainian Energo Company LLC for the trans-portation of 3 million cubic meters of natural gas for the needs of the Odesa Port-Side Plant and a message from the plant about the resumption of production. In January, con-sumption amounted to 9.6 million cubic meters of gas, which means that the submitted applications cover its actual consumption by only a third," the company said.According to Ukrtransgaz, in the February application All-Ukrainian Energo Company in-dicated a volume of 9.6 million cubic meters, while the approximate monthly demand of the Odesa Port-Side Plant in gas is about 60 million cubic meters.According to the Ukrainian legislation, if the actual gas consumption exceeds applications, the consumer should refund the cost of the fuel difference to Ukrtransgaz as a fee for bal-ancing. When the debt appears, the consumer is disconnected from gas supplies, but in the case of the Odesa Port-Side Plant, this is not possible."The Pechersky district court, by its decision dated March 28, 2017 in case No. 757/16733/17-c, forbade Ukrtransgaz from stopping/restricting the transportation of natu-ral gas to the Odesa Port-Side Plant due to non-payment of the existing debt before the fi-nal decision in the court lawsuits related to the recovery of this debt. The court hearings are underway and the final decision has not yet been taken in them," Ukrtransgaz said.As of the end of January, the total debt of the Odesa Port-Side Plant to Ukrtransgaz in-creased to UAH 473.3 million (including UAH 434 million for balancing services and UAH 39.3 million for transportation services)."Thus, the Odesa Port-Side Plant is the largest debtor of Ukrtransgaz among Ukrainian in-dustrial enterprises," Ukrtransgaz said.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSGazprom, Turkmenistan still not negotiating gas supplies, contacts possible towards end-2018MOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Gazprom and Turkmenistan are still not in talks to resume gas supplies, with fresh contacts possible towards the end of the year, when a pause in the contract and arbitration proceedings come to an end, Deputy Russian Energy Minister An-atoly Yanovsky told reporters."Not as far as I know. We signed the pause and this is in effect. There are no talks. It's too soon right now to talk about any negotiations, [but there might be contact] close to the end of the pause," he said.Since January 2016, Gazprom has completely stopped purchases of Turkmen gas having bought 2.8 bcm in 2015. The Turkmen gas sector has yet to offset the negative effect of this.Gazprom had been trying since the 2008 crisis to revise the price of Turkmen gas it was buying. Starting in 2009, Gazprom had bought around 10 billion cubic meters (bcm) of gas per year from Turkmenistan, but said it would curtail those purchases to 4 bcm in 2015. Gazprom paid Turkmenistan the break-even price for gas exports to Europe from January 2015. In the middle of 2015, Gazprom filed a lawsuit against Turkmenistan's state-owned Turkmengaz in Stockholm arbitration, demanding a retroactive revision of prices for Turkmen gas from 2010 through 2015. Gazprom stopped buying Turkmen gas altogether at the beginning of 2016, and the contract was put on hold until the end of 2018.The arbitration case between Gazprom Export and Turkmengaz has been halted until De-cember 31, 2018 with the goal of finding a mutually acceptable solution about further co-operation outside of the framework of the arbitration process.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSNovak discusses prospects for cooperation in oil, gas sector with Syrian petroleum ministerMOSCOW. Feb 5 (Interfax) - Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak has met with the Syrian Petroleum and Mineral Resources Minister Suleiman al-Abbas, the Russian ministry said in a statement.The parties discussed the condition and prospects for bilateral cooperation in the oil and gas sector, in particular, through intergovernmental commissions as well as Russian-Syrian working groups for cooperation in energy."We are placing great importance on the recovery of the Syrian economy, particularly the oil and gas sector, which, of course will facilitate the normalization of the socio-economic situation in the country," Novak was cited as saying in the statement.Speaking in May 2016, Novak said that Syria had asked Zarubezhneft, Lukoil and Gaz-prom Neft for assistance in restoring oil and gas infrastructure. In March 2017, the minis-ter said that Russian companies have started substantial discussions over the issue of Rus-sian companies participating in Syrian production projects.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSRosneft could join Iran's Azar project - Iranian ambassadorMOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Russia and Iran are in talks regarding the possibility of Rus-sian state oil giant Rosneft joining the project to develop the Azar field in Iran, Iran's am-bassador to Russia, Mehdi Sanaei, said in an interview with the Rossiya 24 TV channel."Yes, talks on the Rosneft joining the Azar project in Iran are being held," he said."Several companies are making good headway on the Iranian market. Things are going well for Rosneft, and for Gazprom as well," he said.The ambassador said Gazprom was exploring the possibility of liquefied gas deliveries from Iran. "Indeed, if a year ago we were not very happy with progress being made in economic cooperation, we are now making that progress," he said.Iranian media had reported that Iran and Rosneft were in talks regarding the Azar field. But a Rosneft representative told Interfax on February 5 that the company was "not in talks on joining the Azar project." "The company is interested in developing long-term mu-tually beneficial cooperation with Iranian partners in key areas of business, including ex-ploration and production, services, localization of technology and the training of person-nel. Rosneft signed the relevant agreement with National Iranian Oil Company in Novem-ber 2017," the representative said.Rosneft has signed a strategic cooperation agreement with NIOC as well as a road map to carry out strategic projects in oil and gas production in Iran. Rosneft and NIOC could im-plement up to $30 billion worth of joint oil and gas projects and produce up to 55 million tonnes of oil per year, Rosneft CEO Igor Sechin said at the beginning of November. He said that this included not only oil and gas, but also "carrying out swap operations, supply-ing oil and oil products, training staff and modernizing oil refining."Gazprom Neft is also interested on the Azar project and sees potential in amalgamating the Azar and Shangule fields in Iran into the same infrastructure cluster as the Badra field in Iraq.The ISNA has quoted Nooreddin Shahnazizadeh, head of the Iranian Petroleum Engineer-ing and Development Company, as saying that oil production at Azar, which is in Iran's western Ilam Province near the Iraqi border, reached 15,000 bpd at the beginning of 2017 and was pumping 15,000 bpd in May 2017. It is currently producing 30,000 bpd but could in time be producing 65,000 and eventually 100,000 bpd under the project being proposed by an Iranian-Russian consortium.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSGazprom Neft discovers Novozarinskoye field in Orgenburg Region with geological oil reserves of 11 mln tonnesMOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Gazprom Neft has discovered a new hydrocarbons field in Orenburg Regions; Novozarinskoye, with geological oil reserves of over 11 million tonnes, the company said in a statement.The new field was discovered in the Uransky licensed section, where the Novosamar-skoye field was also discovered in 2016 with geological reserves of over 8 million tonnes. Gazprom Neft is planning to drill another three exploration wells at the Uransky section in 2018.Gazprom Neft has called Orenburg Region one of the oil production centers in its long-term development strategy. The company's key asset in the region is the eastern part of the Orenburgsky field, purchased from Gazprom.CIS, BALTIC and international NEWSShell planning to increase lubricants sales in Russia, CIS from current 120 mln liters to 200 mln liters by 2027MOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - British-Dutch oil company Shell is planning to increase sales of lubricants in Russian and CIS countries from a current 120 million liters to 200 million liters by 2027, Shell Neft CEO Sergei Starodubtsev told journalists."We are expecting to virtually double sales volumes from 120 million liters in 2017 to 200 million liters by 2027," he said.He said that of the 120 million liters, 90 million liters are lubricants manufactured at its plant in Torzhok.Installed capacity at the Torzhok plant is due to be brought up to 200 million liters by 2027. It could account for 90%-95% of Shell products on the Russian market.Shell is planning to open around 40-50 filling stations, operating under the Shell brand, every year over the next 4-5 years, the development and management director of Shell's filling station chain Vitaly Maslov told journalists."We will keep the rate of openings at 40-50 filling stations annually over 4-5 years. This will enable us to double the chain," he said.Shell had 256 filling stations in 2017 with a share of around 2% on the Russian fuel market. Another three filling stations were opened in January 2018 and another one will be opened in Novosibirsk in the next 2-3 weeks.The share of non-fuel sales at Shell's filling stations, shop, cafe, etc... has reached around 30%. "By 2025 we have set ourselves the task of getting the non-fuel segment of the business up to 50%," Maslov said.Shell is implementing a project to introduce a new format of shop at filling stations, inviting fast food restaurants to participate.STATISTICSKazakhstan boosts oil exports 12.4% in 2017ASTANA. Feb 9 (Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ Kazakhstan exported 69.8 million tonnes of oil in 2017 or an increase of 12.4% from a year earlier, according to the factsheet prepared for an extended meeting of the government held in Astana on Friday.In 2017 Kazakhstan produced 72.932 million tonnes of crude oil and 13.269 million tonnes of gas condensate or up 11.2% and 6.5% from a previous year, respectively.STATISTICSKazakhstan's industrial prices up 1.4% in JanASTANA. Feb 8(Interfax-Kazakhstan) â€“ The producer prices for industrial products and services in Kazakhstan rose 1.4% in January 2017 compared to December 2016, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of National Economy said.In the reporting month, in Kazakhstan the prices grew 2.6% in the manufacturing industry, up 0.4% in the mining industry; the prices for industrial products rose 0.9%, industrial service prices up 6.3%, respectively.Over the month, the producer prices for coal increased 6%, diesel up 1.4%, heating oil up 0.7%, crude oil, gasoline and metal ores up 0.3%, liquefied propane and butane down 0.3%; the prices for ferroalloys went up 16.4%, for rolled iron up 3.5%, for lead up 1.1%, while the prices for aluminum went down 3.4%, for zinc down 2.3%, precious metals down 2%, copper down 0.5%.Last month the producer prices for tea rose 2.2%, for vegetable oil up 1.9%, for dairy products up 1.1%, for rice up 0.5% and fell for wheat flour 2.2%, for cereals down 1.4%, for sugar down 1.2%.STATISTICSRussian gas output down 1.3% to 65.3 bcm in JanMOSCOW. Feb 2 (Interfax) - Gas production in Russia fell by 1.3% year-on-year to 65.345 billion cubic meters in January 2018, the latest data from the Central Dispatching Department of the Fuel and Energy Complex (CDU TEK) show.CDU TEK does not separately publish data on production by gas giant Gazprom. They are included as "estimated" figures in the entry "other resource users," which produced 50.534 bcm in January.Leading independent gas producer Novatek produced 3.632 bcm in January. The operators of production sharing agreements produced 2.481 bcm of gas.The biggest gas producers among vertically integrated oil companies were Rosneft, which produced 4.028 bcm in January; Lukoil with 1.848 bcm; Surgutneftegas 0.847 bcm; and Gazprom Neft with 1.456 bcm.STATISTICSOil output in Russia down 1.5% to 46.3 mln tonnes in JanMOSCOW. Feb 2 (Interfax) - Production of oil and gas condensate in Russia totaled 46.306 million tonnes, or 10.949 million barrels per day, in January 2018, 1.5% less than a year earlier, when production amounted to 11.111 bpd, the latest data from the Central Dispatching Department of the Fuel and Energy Complex (CDU TEK) show.The January figure was down by 2.5% from October 2016, when production amounted to 47.494 million tonnes or 11.23 million bpd. October 2016 was taken as the departure point for reducing oil production under an agreement between OPEC and non-OPEC countries.Rosneft produced 16.100 million tonnes in January; Lukoil produced 6.890 million tonnes; Surgutneftegas produced 5.099 million tonnes; Gazprom Neft produced 3.240 million tonnes; Tatneft produced 2.446 million tonnes; Slavneft produced 1.129 million tonnes; Bashneft produced 1.621 million tonnes; and Russneft produced 0.598 million tonnes.Rosneft bought a 50.0755% stake in Bashneft in mid-October 2016, but CDU TEK statistics still count Bashneft's production data separately.Companies with Russian capital and joint ventures with foreign investment produced 6.848 million tonnes of crude in January. CDU TEK does not separately publish data on production by gas giant Gazprom, noting that they are included as estimates in the entry for "other resource users."The operators of production sharing agreements produced 1.542 million tonnes of oil in January.STATISTICSRussian oil exports to non-CIS down 1.3% in 2017, gas up 6.8% - customsMOSCOW. Feb 7 (Interfax) - Russia exported 234.5 million tonnes of oil to non-CIS countries in 2017, 1.3% less than in 2016, the Federal Customs Service (FCS) said.Natural gas exports rose 6.8% to 175.9 billion cubic meters (bcm).Fuel and energy accounted for 63.2% of Russian exports to the non-CIS in 2017, up from 62.1% in 2016. Overall fuel and energy exports to non-CIS countries rose 27.1% in value and 1.7% in natural terms.Exports by volume rose 10.3% for coal, 6.8% for natural gas and 1.4% for diesel fuel, but declined 26.0% for gasoline.Fuel and energy accounted for 33.2% of Russian exports to the CIS, up from 32.4% in 2016. The value of fuel and energy exports to CIS countries increased 29.4% and physical export volumes were up 5.3%. Exports by volume were up 36.1% for petroleum coke, 35.7% for oil products and 0.9% for natural gas, but declined 21.2% for electricity and 2.3% for natural gas.Russia exported 252.6 million tonnes of crude oil worth $93.3 billion to all destinations and 210 bcm of gas worth $38.1 billion in 2017.STATISTICSRussian oil exports outside CIS drop 3.8% in JanMOSCOW. Feb 2 (Interfax) - Exports of Russian oil to countries outside the CIS fell 3.8% year-on-year to 19.795 million tonnes (4.681 million barrels per day) in January 2018, the latest figures from the Central Dispatching Department of the Fuel and Energy Complex (CDU TEK) show.Oil exports to outside the CIS through pipeline monopoly Transneft totaled 17.75 million tonnes (of which 16.13 million tonnes were Russian resources) in January, and 3.666 million tonnes bypassed Transneft.Oil shipments through the Novorossiysk port via Transneft's pipeline system totaled 1.415 million tonnes in January. The figures were 3.398 million tonnes for the Primorsk port; 2.699 million tonnes for Kozmino; and 1.399 million tonnes for Ust-Luga.State oil major Rosneft exported 8.712 million tonnes of oil outside the CIS via Transneft in January; Surgutneftegas exported respectively 2.465 million tonnes; Lukoil exported 1.685 million tonnes; Gazprom Neft exported 0.787 million tonnes; and Tatneft exported 0.870 million tonnes.Companies that are not part of vertically integrated oil companies exported 1.336 million tonnes of oil to countries outside the CIS through Transneft in January.Transit shipments totaled 1.62 million tonnes in January for Kazakhstan; 79,700 tonnes for Azerbaijan; and 138,000 tonnes for Belarus.Russian crude exports to countries in the CIS rose by 14.3% to 1.575 million tonnes in January. Crude exports to Belarus grew by 12.5% to 1.55 million tonnes, and exports to Uzbekistan via Transneft's system totaled 24,900 tonnes.STATISTICSUkraine ups gas production 3.1% in JanKYIV. Feb 2 (Interfax) - Ukraine raised gas production 3.1% year-on-year in January to 1.774 billion cubic meters, pipeline operator Ukrtransgaz said, quoting preliminary data.According to Interfax's calculations, gas production by PJSC Ukrgazvydobuvannia rose 3.3% to 1.303 bcm while production by Ukrnafta fell 16.7% to 91 million cubic meters.Ukraine increased natural gas transit through the gas transportation system (GTS) by 32.1% year-on-year in January to 6.056 bcm, the lowest monthly figure in seven years except for January 2015, Ukrtransgaz said.Transit of natural gas to the European countries across Ukraine totaled 5.689 bcm and to Moldova - 366.1 mcm.Ukraine cut natural gas import by 44.8% year-on-year to 801.5 mcm in January. Imports from Slovakia amounted to 596.7 mcm, from Hungary to 99.8 mcm and Poland to 105.1 mcm.StorageUkraine withdrew 2.178 bcm of natural gas from its underground gas storage facilities in January 2018, 50% more than in December 2017.Gas stocks in Ukrainian underground storage facilities fell by 26.3% or 4.461 bcm, to 12.515 bcm between October 24, when the heating season started, and January 31 inclusive.According to Interfax's calculations, the country withdrew an average daily 24.85 mcm of gas from underground storage in November and 46.05 mcm in December last year, and 70.24 mcm in January this year, including 68.27 mcm on January 31.On January 31, 2017 Ukraine pumped 91.94 mcm from its facilities which had 9.885 bcm of gas stored, on January 31, 2016 - 52.67 mcm (11.112 bcm) and on January 31, 2015 - 56.04 mcm (9.311 bcm).Ukraine's underground gas storage facilities held 12.269 billion cubic meters (bcm) of gas on February 3, 2018, compared with 9.639 bcm on the same day in 2017, 10.95 bcm in 2016 and 9.171 bcm in 2015.Ukraine is able to withdraw about 1% of stockpiles from underground storage each day. In other words, it has the ability to withdraw 100-120 mcm from storage per day in February.In fact, it has yet to withdraw 100 mcm in any day so far in the 2017/2018 heating season: the biggest withdrawals recorded so far are 94-95 mcm on separate days in the final 10 days of January.Relatively warm weather also kept the withdrawals below 100 mcm in the first days of February, despite the 50% drop in imports: it withdrew 78.9 mcm from underground storage on February 1, 84.9 mcm on February 2 and 81.7 mcm on February 3.ImportsUkraine cut imports of natural gas by 44.8% or 651.5 million cubic meters (mcm) in January 2018 year-over-year, to 801.5 mcm, according to data from public joint-stock company Ukrtransgaz.According to Interfax calculations, imports from Slovakia in January 2018 amounted to 596.7 mcm, Hungary to 99.8 mcm, and Poland to 105.1 mcm.Ukraine has not been importing natural gas under the contract with PJSC Gazprom for more than two years (since November 26, 2015), purchasing resources exclusively on its western border.Ukraine increased imports of natural gas by 26.8% or 2.972 billion cubic meters (bcm) in 2017, to 14.05 bcm. Imports from Slovakia in 2017 amounted to 9.91 bcm, Hungary to 2.835 bcm, and Poland to 1.305 bcm.Ukrtransgaz, fully owned by Naftogaz Ukrainy, operates a system of trunk gas pipelines and 12 underground gas storage facilities in the country.Ukraine halved imports of natural gas from EU countries in the first days of February, including a 67% cut in imports from Slovakia, according to data from Ukrtransgaz.Ukraine imported 25.856 million cubic meters of gas each day on average from Europe in January, according to Interfax calculations. That figure fell to 12.513 mcm in the first three days of February. Imports from Slovakia declined more steeply, to 6.313 mcm per day in February 1-3, down from 19.248 mcm per day in January.Slovakian gas transport operator Eustream reported that Ukraine has submitted orders to receive 6.304 mcm per day on February 4 and 5, indicating that Naftogaz Ukrainy intends to maintain that import volume on the route until the end of the month.Ukraine boosted gas imports from European countries by 27% or 3 billion cubic meters (bcm) in 2017 as a whole, to 14.1 bcm, Naftogaz reported."The important result of the year was the increase in the volumes and the share of imports by private traders and gas consumers. Last year these companies imported 1.8 times more gas than in 2016: 5.4 bcm against 2.9 bcm. In 2017, 67 companies imported gas to Ukraine (34 companies in 2016)," the company said.Last year Naftogaz imported 8.7 bcm of gas from the European market, which is 6% or 0.5 bcm more than a year ago. The company purchased gas from 13 European suppliers compared with 15 suppliers in 2016."No one of these companies supplies more than 30% of the total volume of imported gas," the company said.Naftogaz said that in 2017 the company did not buy gas from Russia's Gazprom.STATISTICSAzerbaijan ups oil production to 814,600 bpd in Jan, compliant with OPEC+ agreementBAKU. Feb 6 (Interfax) - Daily oil production in Azerbaijan was 814,600 barrels in January 2018, the Azerbaijani Energy Ministry said in a statement.This included 759,700 barrels of oil and 54,900 barrels of condensate.Azerbaijan pledged under the agreement between OPEC and non-OPEC countries to maintain its own oil production at than 835,000 barrels.In 2017 daily oil production in Azerbaijan was 781,900 barrels. The country also fulfilled its commitments it undertook to reduce output in January.In January 2017, daily oil production in Azerbaijan was 793,900 barrels, in February - 776,400 barrels, in March - 733,300 barrels, in April - 781,100 barrels, in May - 785,300 barrels, in June - 793,700 barrels, July - 796,700 barrels, August - 734,800 barrels, in September - 785,700 barrels, in October - 800,600 barrels, in November - 790,700 barrels and in December - 810,000 barrels.According to the Energy Ministry data, in January 2017, daily oil exports from Azerbaijan stood at 624,200 barrels, condensate - 54,900 barrels and petroleum products - 14,300 barrels.* * * * *Copyright (c) 2018 Interfax-Kazakhstan. All rights reserved.Issued by Interfax-Kazakhstan news agency. www.interfax.kz85a, Dostyk str., Almaty, 480100, Kazakhstan. Phones: +7 (3272) 506516, subscription: +7 (3272) 506628. Fax: +7 (3272) 501389. E-mail. news@interfax.kzBy InterfaxCopyright of Kazakhstan Oil & Gas Weekly is the property of Interfax-America Inc. and its content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. column5: ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - Theoilrefining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries in 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes, 6% higher than actual refining in 2017 and 9% higher than the refining target last year, according to the factsheet prepared for an expanded government meeting in Astana on Friday. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: Crude oil refining in Kazakhstan targeted to increase 6% in 2018.
column10: Crude oil refining in Kazakhstan targeted to increase 6% in 2018ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The oil refining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries in 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes, 6% higher than actual refining in 2017 and 9% higher than the refining target last year, according to the factsheet prepared for an expanded government meeting in Astana on Friday.Domestic refineries processed 14.9 million tonnes of crude oil in 2017 (compared with the target of 14.5 million tonnes), 2.8% more than in 2016.Petroleum bitumen output is expected to amount to 740,000 tonnes in 2018.In 2017, Kazakhstan produced 731,000 tonnes of bitumen or an increase of 46.7% from 2016. Kazakhstan exported 97,000 tonnes of bitumen to Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and China in 2017.Coal production is targeted at 107 million tonnes in 2018 compared with actual production of 111.118 million tonnes in 2017.The level of gasification in the country is slated to rise to 47.65% from 47.38% as of the end of 2017."Sixteen gasification projects at a total cost of 12.8 billion tenge will be carried out in six regions this year: Jambyl, South Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, West Kazakhstan and Almaty regions," the materials say.Kz jh ak(Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)Copyright (c) 2018 Interfax. All rights reserved.By InterfaxCopyright of Central Asia General Newswire is the property of Interfax-America Inc. and its content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. However, users may print, download, or email articles for individual use.

column9: U.S. Should End Its Export Ban On Crude Oil, Study Says.
column10: RENEE MONTAGNE: We have some economic news. A study finds consumers would benefit from a change in U.S. oil policy. The study examines the effects of ending the decade-long ban on exporting U.S. crude oil. There's been a ban since the Arab oil embargo of 1970s. NPR's John Ydstie reports.JOHN YDSTIE: Jason Bordoff is a co-author of the study. He's a former energy adviser in the Obama White House and now directs the Columbia University Center on Global Energy Policy. He says convincing consumers and politicians to end the export ban on crude is not an easy sell.JASON BORDOFF: People worry that allowing oil exports may lead to higher pump prices. Kind of intuitively, you might think we're sending our oil overseas, there's less for us or we'll have to pay more for it.YDSTIE: But Bordoff says evidence and economic theory suggest that ending the export ban would put downward pressure on gasoline prices. The reason is that U.S. consumers haven't been getting the full benefit of low U.S. crude prices.BORDOFF: Because the price consumers are paying for gasoline is being set by the world price of oil, not by the U.S. price.YDSTIE: And during most of the past few years, the world price has been well above the U.S. price - as much as $20 a barrel higher. That happened partly because of a 60 percent surge in U.S. oil production that led to an oversupply of crude on the U.S. market that couldn't be exported. So a gap opened between the price of U.S. crude and the global price of oil. But U.S. consumers didn't see much benefit according to Bordoff.BORDOFF: To the extent there's any discount on the U.S. price compared to the world price that is a benefit that accrues to refiners, not to consumers.YDSTIE: So not surprisingly, says Bordoff, refiners are lobbying hard to continue the export ban.BORDOFF: I think if you were a refiner, you'd rather buy your crude cheaper if you could.YDSTIE: And independent oil refiners take issue with the collusion of Bordoff's study. Jay Hauck is the executive director of the organization called CRUDE.JAY HAUCK: The oil export ban benefits consumers. It benefits businesses in the United States. It has very broad and deep support, and it also has a very strong national security component.YDSTIE: Hauck points to a study by Barclays that argues that refiners did pass to consumers most of the savings they enjoyed from processing lower-cost U.S. crude in recent years. And Hauck says the export ban protects U.S. energy security.HAUCK: It helps insulate the United States from volatility and unpredictable global crude markets.YDSTIE: Including market manipulation by OPEC.HAUCK: For us to simply unilaterally disarm seems unwise.YDSTIE: But Bordoff argues that by lifting the export ban and becoming a bigger player in the oil market, the U.S. will gain influence over global prices. He also says lifting the ban would give the U.S. more credibility on global trade issues.BORDOFF: Allowing traded energy is consistent with our past and our present U.S. trade policy priorities.YDSTIE: The U.S. already allows exports of products like gasoline. And the Obama administration recently loosened the crude export ban a bit by allowing exports of lightly processed crude called condensate. But opposition from environmentalists who say lifting the ban would promote more fossil fuel use is constraining further White House action. Big oil producers have lobbied hard to eliminate the ban, but they're concerned they don't yet have enough support in the Congress to win. So a vote on lifting the ban on crude oil exports could be a ways off. John Ydstie, NPR News, Washington.Copyright of Morning Edition (NPR) is the property of National Public Radio, Inc.  The copyright in an individual article may be maintained by the author in certain cases.  Content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. However, users may print, download, or email articles for individual use. Source: Morning Edition (NPR), 01/20/2015Item: 6XN201501201110

column5: Dublin - Research and Markets has announced the addition of the "NigeriaCrudeOilRefinery Outlook to 2021" report to their offering.
column9: Nigeria Crude Oil Refinery Outlook to 2021
column10: Dublin - Research and Markets has announced the addition of the "Nigeria Crude Oil Refinery Outlook to 2021" report to their offering."Nigeria Crude Oil Refinery Outlook to 2021" is a comprehensive report on crude oil refinery industry in Nigeria. The report provides oil production, consumption, exports and imports details from 2000 to 2020 along with oil reserves for the period 2000 to 2015. The report also provides details on oil refineries such as name, type, operational status, operator apart from capacity data for the major processing units, for all active and planned refineries in Nigeria till 2021. column5: ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The government of Kazakhstan will revise some macroeconomic parameters upward, including the referenceoilprice used in this year's budget, Deputy Minister of the National Economy Ruslan Dalenov. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: Kazakhstan's 2018 budget may assume higher crude oil price.
column10: Kazakhstan's 2018 budget may assume higher crude oil priceASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The government of Kazakhstan will revise some macroeconomic parameters upward, including the reference oil price used in this year's budget, Deputy Minister of the National Economy Ruslan Dalenov."This concerns, first of all, the price of crude oil. Earlier, the budget was based on $45 a barrel for this year. The price of oil is currently slightly more than $60 a barrel, while the consensus forecast of the UN, WB, and IMF averages $58. We are now considering what benchmark price to pick for this year," Dalenov said at a briefing in Astana.The parameters for exports and manufacturing will also be revised upward.He noted that the economic situation in the country has generally improved."GDP grew by 4% in 2017, which is higher than the average rate around the world and in neighboring countries. I can say that today, there is no crisis in the country," Dalenov said.Kz mc ak(Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)Copyright (c) 2018 Interfax. column5: ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - Theoilrefining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries in 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes, 6% higher than actual refining in 2017 and 9% higher than the refining target last year, according to the factsheet prepared for an expanded government meeting in Astana on Friday. [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: Crude oil refining in Kazakhstan targeted to increase 6% in 2018.
column10: Crude oil refining in Kazakhstan targeted to increase 6% in 2018ASTANA. Feb 12 (Interfax) - The oil refining target for Kazakhstan-based refineries in 2018 is set at 15.8 million tonnes, 6% higher than actual refining in 2017 and 9% higher than the refining target last year, according to the factsheet prepared for an expanded government meeting in Astana on Friday.Domestic refineries processed 14.9 million tonnes of crude oil in 2017 (compared with the target of 14.5 million tonnes), 2.8% more than in 2016.Petroleum bitumen output is expected to amount to 740,000 tonnes in 2018.In 2017, Kazakhstan produced 731,000 tonnes of bitumen or an increase of 46.7% from 2016. Kazakhstan exported 97,000 tonnes of bitumen to Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and China in 2017.Coal production is targeted at 107 million tonnes in 2018 compared with actual production of 111.118 million tonnes in 2017.The level of gasification in the country is slated to rise to 47.65% from 47.38% as of the end of 2017."Sixteen gasification projects at a total cost of 12.8 billion tenge will be carried out in six regions this year: Jambyl, South Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, West Kazakhstan and Almaty regions," the materials say.Kz jh ak(Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)Copyright (c) 2018 Interfax. column4: JAGGED Peak Energy LLCSTOCK pricesEARNINGS per shareBUSINESS revenueRELATIVE strength index (Securities)
column5: The article report on Jagged Peak Energy LLC' highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating as on May 3, 2018. It refers to estimates of earnings growth of 100% to 10 cents per share on revenue of 117.7 million dollars. It highlights the need for the energy stock to maintain a solid uptrend since its IPO on January 27, 2018 as its relative strength line tumbled in the first quarter.
column9: Amid Rising Crude Oil Prices, This Top Energy Stock Nears An Entry.
column10: With crude oil prices hovering near multi-year highs, leading energy stocks are some of the stock market's top-performing ideas. Top energy stock  Jagged Peak Energy (JAG) is shaping a potential buy point.The IPO Leader competes with the likes of Concho Resources (CXO) and Diamondback Energy (FANG) in the southern Delaware sub-basin of the Permian production area.With a highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, Jagged Peak is the No. 1-ranked stock in the Oil & Gas U.S. Exploration and Production industry group. The Composite Rating blends key fundamental and technical metrics to gauge a stock's quality.Rounding out the top three stocks in the group are Energen (EGN) and Parsley Energy (PE). Both are pulling back to their 10-week lines after recent breakouts.Jagged Peak's industry group is ranked No. 9 out of 197 groups, moving up from No. 56 six weeks ago.According to RBC Capital Markets, potential catalysts include spacing tests between wells at Whiskey River and Cochise — two of the company's areas in the Southern Delaware basin located in West Texas. Positive results from this testing could add up to 400 locations to the company's inventory.Quarterly earnings results are due out May 11 before the market open. Consensus estimates show earnings growth of 100% to 10 cents per share on revenue of $117.7 million.There's also a new CEO at the helm. In March, Joseph Jaggers retired and James Kleckner, an independent director of the company, became the newest CEO.Since its IPO on Jan. 27, the new issue has yet to maintain a solid uptrend, despite two separate breakouts. Now, the stock is shaping a cup-with-handle base with a 15.08 buy point.A big weakness is the stock's relative strength line — painted in blue on every MarketSmith chart — which tumbled in the first quarter. It remains well off its former highs. Look for that to improve if the market is able to right itself.According to the IBD Stock Checkup, the stock is seeing solid institutional demand. It has a B Accumulation/Distribution Rating and a 1.4 up/down volume ratio. For comparison, a neutral up/down reading is 1.0.RELATED:Ferrari Plus These IBD 50 Names To Report: Investing Action PlanTop Retail Name Fends Off Industry Weakness And Is Near A Buy PointThe 'Apple Of Oil' Near Buy Point Ahead Of Earnings After The CloseEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalIPO Stock News And Analysis: Find Today's Top New IssuesGraph: https://research.investors.com/ibdchartswp.aspx?cht=pvc&type=daily&symbol=JAGBy SCOTT LEHTONENCopyright of Investors Business Daily is the property of Investor's Business Daily and its content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. column5: The article reports that the rise in thecrudeand fuel inventories, lead to the fall in theoil. It mentions that the supply ofcrudeoilrose by 2.84 million barrels. It states that Kuwait expects the compliance with the partnership between OPEC and non-OPEC nations. It mentions that the stock of gasoline rose in several months.
column9: Oil Declines In New York As U.S. Crude And Fuel Supplies Gain.
column10: FuturesOil declined after a U.S. government report showed that crude and fuel inventories increased.Futures fell 0.8% in New York. Crude supplies rose 2.84 million barrels in the week ended Jan. 20, the Energy Information Administration said. Gasoline stockpiles climbed a fourth week. While Kuwait expects complete compliance with a pact between OPEC and non-OPEC nations, some countries haven't fully carried out the cuts yet, said Oil Minister Essam Al-Marzouk, who chairs the panel that will oversee the curbs."There's lots of talk about OPEC, non-OPEC production cuts but the fact remains that U.S. crude supplies are very high and rising," Thomas Finlon, director of Energy Analytics Group in Wellington, Fla., said by phone. "Gasoline always rises at this time of year but this is different. I am surprised by the velocity of supply growth."Oil has held above $50 a barrel since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and 11 other nations agreed late last year to curb supply by about 1.8 million barrels a day. While Saudi Arabia says more than 80% of the targeted reduction has been implemented since the deal took effect on Jan. 1, the International Energy Agency predicted a rebound in shale output as prices rise. U.S. drillers last week added the most rigs to oil fields since 2013.West Texas Intermediate for March delivery dropped 43 cents, or 0.8%, to $52.75 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Total volume traded was about 7% above the 100-day average.Are you getting the most out of IBD? Our Getting Started Guide can help!Brent for March settlement declined 36 cents to $55.08 a barrel on the London-based ICE Futures Europe exchange. The global benchmark crude closed at a $2.33 premium to WTI.Nationwide crude inventories rose to 488.3 million, the highest since November. Supplies at Cushing, Okla., the biggest U.S. storage hub and the delivery point for WTI, fell 284,000 barrels last week.Refineries processed 16 million barrels a day of crude last week, down 421,000 barrels from the prior week, the report showed. Refineries operated at 88.3% of capacity, down 2.4 percentage points from the prior week, and the lowest since November.U.S. gasoline stockpiles rose 6.8 million barrels to 253.2 million, the highest since February. Inventories of distillate fuel, a category that includes diesel and heating oil, increased 76,000 to 169.1 million.Gasoline futures for February delivery dropped 3.3% to $1.5238 a gallon, the lowest close since Dec. 9.Oil prices fell Wednesday amid worries over rising supply. (© Jim Parkin/stock.adobe.com)BY BLOOMBERG NEWSCopyright of Investors Business Daily is the property of Investor's Business Daily and its content may not be copied or emailed to multiple sites or posted to a listserv without the copyright holder's express written permission. column5: TransMontaigne Partners L.P. (NYSE:TLP) (the “Partnership” or “we”) announced today that it has completed the previously announced acquisition of the Martinez Terminal and Richmond Terminal from an affiliate of Plains All American Pipeline, L.P. (the “West Coast Acquisition”). As a result of the West Coast Acquisition, the Partnership has expanded its storage and terminaling footprint into the San Francisco Bay Area refining complex. Plains will continue to operate the terminals on behalf of the Partnership until the Partnership receives all permits and approvals necessary to operate the terminals, which we expect to occur by the end of February 2018.   [ABSTRACT FROM PUBLISHER]
column9: TransMontaigne Partners L.P. Announces Closing of Acquisition of Two West Coast Refined Product and Crude Oil Terminals from Plains All American Pipeline, L.P.
column10: TransMontaigne Partners L.P. (NYSE:TLP) (the “Partnership” or “we”) announced today that it has completed the previously announced acquisition of the Martinez Terminal and Richmond Terminal from an affiliate of Plains All American Pipeline, L.P. (the “West Coast Acquisition”). As a result of the West Coast Acquisition, the Partnership has expanded its storage and terminaling footprint into the San Francisco Bay Area refining complex. Plains will continue to operate the terminals on behalf of the Partnership until the Partnership receives all permits and approvals necessary to operate the terminals, which we expect to occur by the end of February 2018.   The Partnership funded the purchase price for the West Coast Acquisition with borrowings under its revolving credit facility. In connection with closing the West Coast Acquisition, the Partnership amended the revolving credit facility to increase the lender commitments from $600 million to $850 million, and the lender commitments may be further increased under certain conditions to $1.1 billion through an accordion feature.   About TransMontaigne Partners L.P.   TransMontaigne Partners L.P. is a terminaling and transportation company based in Denver, Colorado with operations in the United States along the Gulf Coast, in the Midwest, in Houston and Brownsville, Texas, along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers, and in the Southeast. We provide integrated terminaling, storage, transportation and related services for customers engaged in the distribution and marketing of light refined petroleum products, heavy refined petroleum products, crude oil, chemicals, fertilizers and other liquid products. Light refined products include gasolines, diesel fuels, heating oil and jet fuels; heavy refined products include residual fuel oils and asphalt. We do not purchase or market products that we handle or transport. News and additional information about TransMontaigne Partners L.P. is available the Partnership’s website: www.transmontaignepartners.com.   Forward-Looking Statements   This press release includes statements that may constitute forward-looking statements for federal securities laws. Although the Partnership believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, actual results could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements as a result of certain risk factors, including, the ability to obtain required permits and other approvals on a timely basis. Additional important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the Partnership’s expectations and may adversely affect its business and results of operations are disclosed in “Item 1A. Risk Factors” in the Partnership’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2016, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on March 14, 2017.
